questions.text: Which of these does not fall under the category of catatonia?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Akathisia
 
  • Akathisia is not a part of catatonia.
  • Akathisia is defined as an inability to remain still. It is a neuropsychiatric syndrome that is associated with psychomotor restlessness. The individual with akathisia will generally experience an intense sensation of unease or an inner restlessness that usually involves the lower extremities. 
  • It is also a known extrapyramidal side effect of anti-dopaminergic drugs like Anti-psychotics (Haloperidol/Fluphenazine) 
  • It typically tends to develop 5-50 days post antipsychotic initiation and management includes using drugs like Propranolol/Benzodiazepines. 
Other options- 
  • Ambivalence- having contradictory feelings
  • Ambitendency- acting opposite ways
  • Akinesia- No movement

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 343-345, 926.

questions.text: Where do we see feelings of uneasiness and an excessive sense of responsibility?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Obsessive-Compulsive disorder
 
  • Pathological doubts (feelings of uncertainty) and an excessive sense of responsibility are both symptoms/types of OCD
  • Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is a disorder in which people have recurring, unwanted thoughts, ideas, or sensations (obsessions) that give them feelings of uneasiness. To get rid of the thoughts, they feel driven to do something repetitively (compulsions).
  • Responsibility OCD is a subtype of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) in which you experience an intense and irrational belief that you're responsible for preventing harm or negative events, even when they're beyond your control.
Other options- 
  • Phobia is unnecessary fear of something
  • Generalized Anxiety Disorder has free floating anxiety 


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 422.

questions.text: The following best describes a state of mutism and akinesis in which the patient is only somewhat alert:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Stupor

Stupor
Stupor is a condition in which a person is almost completely nonresponsive and reacts only to strong stimuli, like pain. It is characterized by the absence of critical mental function and a very small degree of consciousness. The patient is usually mute/akinetic.

Definition of other terms

Delirium
A disordered state of awareness or of the mind, especially a sudden, a brief condition brought on by fever, intoxication, or other physical conditions, and characterized by symptoms like confusion, agitation, disorientation, and hallucinations.

Oneroid State
The psychopathological condition known as oneiroid syndrome (OS), also known as dream-like delusional derangement of consciousness, is characterized by a kaleidoscopic quality of psychopathological experiences in which reality, illusions, and hallucinations are combined into one.

Twilight State
An altered state of consciousness in which the person is momentarily ignorant of his or her surroundings has momentary auditory or visual hallucinations and reacts to them by acting irrationally, such as stripping off in public, fleeing, or inflicting harm.



Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 341.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman fantasies about chopping her fingers, plots for it, and even attempts it, but she never follows through. She claims that she doesn't feel bad about thinking such things. Additionally, she claims that she is helpless to stop the upsetting thoughts. Either a seizure ends the thoughts, or they naturally stop on their own. What one of the following is the reason?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. FORCED THINKING
 
  • The given clinical vignette describes Forced thinking which includes different types of intrusive thoughts. These are the most common pre-ictal events, commonly seen in Frontal Lobe Epilepsy.
  • Obsession is a type of intrusive thought that is recurrent, persistent, and unwanted. The person experiences these thoughts as distressing and anxiety-provoking, and they often attempt to neutralize them by performing compulsive behaviors. Obsession is Ego Dystonic, hence patient feels distressed with these thoughts but in the above scenario patient does not feel bad about these thoughts hence it is unlikely to be obsession.
  • Thought insertion is defined by the ICD-10 as the delusion that one's thoughts are not one's own, but rather belong to someone else and have been inserted into one's mind.


Reference: Lishman's Organic Psychiatry, 4th edition, Page no 557.
Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page no 251.

questions.text: Which of the following provisions of the 2017 Mental Health Act are not based on the WHO mental health gap action ?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Screening family members
 
  • The goal of the Mental Health Gap Action Program (MHGAP) is to provide care, raise awareness, offer psychosocial support, build communication, and administer medicine to people with mental, neurological, and substance use disorders.
  • Screening of family members is not a part of MHGAP.
  • The Mental Health Act 2017 includes provisions to ensure that people with mental disorders are involved in decisions about their care and treatment, and that they receive information about their condition and treatment options in a way that they can understand. 
  • The Mental Health Act 2017 includes provisions to promote social support for people with mental disorders, including access to community-based services and support networks.


Reference: The Mental Health Care Act (MHCA) 2017 https://www.indiacode.nic.in/handle/123456789/2249
Chadda, Rakesh K. “Influence of the new mental health legislation in India.” BJPsych international vol. 17,1 (2020): 20-22. doi:10.1192/bji.2019.18
WHO Mental health Gap action Programme (mhGAP) https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789241596206

questions.text: What is the SPIKES protocol used for?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Communication with patients/attendants regarding bad news

SPIKES protocol is used for communication with patients/attendants regarding bad news.
 
The spikes protocol includes:
 
S-SETTING UP the Interview
P-Assessing the patient's PERCEPTION
I-Obtaining the patient's INVITATION
K-Giving KNOWLEDGE and information to the patient
E-Addressing the patient's EMOTIONS with EMPATHIC responses.
S-STRATEGY and SUMMARY


Reference: Baile, W F et al. “SPIKES-A six-step protocol for delivering bad news: application to the patient with cancer.” The oncologist vol. 5,4 (2000): 302-11. doi:10.1634/theoncologist.5-4-302

questions.text: The mental healthcare act states that a person who is not a minor and has a known psychiatric disease or is receiving treatment may choose the caregiver and the course of therapy. What is it known as?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Advance directive  
 
  • According to the Mental Healthcare Act 2017, a person who is not a minor and has a known psychiatric disease or is receiving treatment may choose his/her caretaker and the type of care. This is known as an Advance directive.
  • Advance directives are preferences and decisions for medical treatment when a patient's condition is thought to be terminal.




Reference: The Mental Health Care Act (MHCA) 2017 https://www.indiacode.nic.in/handle/123456789/2249
Chadda, Rakesh K. “Influence of the new mental health legislation in India.” BJPsych international vol. 17,1 (2020): 20-22. doi:10.1192/bji.2019.18

questions.text: Which of the following does not belong to Beck's cognitive triad?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Guilt
 
  • According to Aaron Beck's theory from 1976, there are three different types of negative thoughts that are present in depression. His cognitive theory of depression includes the triad:
  1. Negative thoughts about the self - Worthlessness
  2. Negative thoughts about the world- Helplessness and
  3. Negative thoughts about the future - Hopelesness
  • The three components are interconnected and reinforce each other.
  • Guilt is a negative emotion that arises from a sense of responsibility for doing something wrong or causing harm to others.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 355.

questions.text: Which of the following is an illustration of a placebo?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Sham surgery
 
  • A placebo is an inert substance or treatment that has no therapeutic effect on the patient's condition but is given for the psychological benefit of the patient, to satisfy the patient's expectation of receiving treatment, or to serve as a control in a clinical trial.
  • Sham surgery is a surgical procedure that omits a phase that is believed to be therapeutically important.
  • Sham operations serve as an essential scientific control in clinical trials of surgical intervention. This is due to the fact that it isolates the treatment's intended effects as opposed to the unintended consequences brought on by anaesthesia, wound healing, pre- and post-operative care, and the patient's feeling of having undergone a routine procedure.
  • Therefore, sham surgery provides a similar function to placebo medications in removing biases like the placebo effect.

Reference: Wolf, Brian R, and Joseph A Buckwalter. “Randomized surgical trials and "sham" surgery: relevance to modern orthopaedics and minimally invasive surgery.” The Iowa orthopaedic journal vol. 26 (2006): 107-11 doi: https://ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1888585/

questions.text: A patient feels that he is the most significant person in the world, and because of their jealousy, his family, neighbors, and even strangers are always watching him giving him secret looks, and then trying to hurt him. He believes the news on TV about certain politicians is about him. His wife says otherwise and claims that he only recently began acting in this manner before being brought to OPD and he was/is working as a teacher. What is he most likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given description suggests that the patient is having delusions of grandiosity, persecution, and reference.
 
  • Delusion of grandeur: An exaggerated perception of one's significance, power, or identity is referred to as a delusion of grandeur. (Most significant person in the world)
  • Delusion of persecution: The erroneous belief that one is being harassed or persecuted; frequently observed in litigious patients who have a pathological propensity to file lawsuits over fictitious abuse. (trying to hurt him)
  • Delusion of reference: The false assumption that someone else's behavior is a reflection of their own, or that things, events, or other people have a unique or exceptional significance that is typically negative. (TV news about him)


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 3637.

choices.text: Digit span forward up to 7 digits with 2 skips allowed
Digit span backward upto 2 digits with 2 skips allowed

questions.text: Which of the following is the test concentration?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is Option 1: Serial (100-7) subtraction test up to 5 steps.

This is because the Serial (100-7) subtraction test requires sustained attention, mental focus, and concentration. The task involves repeatedly subtracting 7 from 100, which demands the ability to stay focused over multiple steps, making it a test specifically designed to assess concentration.

Here's why the other options aren't focused on concentration in the same way:

  • Option 2 (Digit span forward up to 7 digits with 2 skips allowed): This is a test of short-term memory, specifically how many digits a person can remember in the same order.
  • Option 3 (Digit span backward up to 2 digits with 2 skips allowed): This is a test of working memory, as it requires the individual to not only hold the digits in memory but also to manipulate them by reversing the order.

Since both of the digit span tasks primarily assess memory capacity rather than concentration, Option 1 is the best choice for testing concentration.




Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 203.
Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 205

questions.text: Which of the following is not a disorder of "form of thought"?
questions.solution:
• Amongst the given options, the Thought block (option 3) is the most appropriate answer.
  • Thought blocking occurs when there is a sudden arrest of the train of thought, leaving a ‘blank’. An entirely new thought may then begin.
  • Thought block is a disorder of continuity of thinking (stream of thought), not a disorder of form, which means that thought block is not due to an inability to come up with ideas (form) but instead is due to an inability to maintain a train of thought (stream). People with this disorder may have difficulty organizing or connecting their ideas and concepts together in a coherent way. 
Note: Certain textbooks consider thought block as a disorder of the form of thought. However, Fish's Clinical Psychopathology (followed at AIIMS) clearly mentions Thought block as a disorder of continuity of thinking (stream of thought).
Hence, in INICET, option (3) should be marked [Controversial question]



Reference: Fish's Clinical Psychopathology, 3rd edition, Page no 36.

choices.text: Physiological needs - Safety - Belonging - Self-esteem - Self- actualization

questions.text: Which of these represents the true hierarchy of needs according to Maslow?
questions.solution:
Correct sequence according to Maslow’s hierarchy is : Physiological needs - Safety - Belonging - Self-esteem - Self­ actualization.





Reference: Kenrick, Douglas T et al. “Renovating the Pyramid of Needs: Contemporary Extensions Built Upon Ancient Foundations.” Perspectives on psychological science : a journal of the Association for Psychological Science vol. 5,3 (2010): 292-314. doi:10.1177/1745691610369469
Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 181.

questions.text: A study comparing the behavioral and developmental changes in a normal brain with a damaged brain is:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Neuropsychology
 
  • Clinical neuropsychology is the application of neuropsychological knowledge to the assessment, management, rehabilitation of the people who have suffered illness or injury(particularly to the brain), which has caused neurocognitive problems.
  • Thus, comparing the behavioral and developmental changes in a normal brain with a damaged brain.
  • Neurodevelopmental psychology  is a subfield of psychology that focuses on the study of how the brain and nervous system develop over time, particularly during childhood.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 236.

questions.text: The self awareness regarding the disease in a psychiatric patient in the mental status examination is called:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Insight
 
  • Insight is an important element of a mental status examination and refers to an individual’s awareness and understanding of their mental illness.
  • Having insight regarding one's illness means that a patient is aware of their disorder and can accurately identify the symptoms that they are experiencing. It implies a level of awareness and understanding of their illness, as well as the potential effects of their disorder on their daily functioning.
  • Insight can be evaluated through direct questioning and observations of the individual's behavior. Without insight, individuals may be unaware of their symptoms and the need for treatment, making proper diagnosis and care more difficult.
Other options:
  • Orientation: State of awareness of oneself and one's surroundings in terms of time, place, and person. (Option 2)
  • Judgment: Mental act of comparing or evaluating choices within the framework of a given set of values for the purpose of electing a course of action. (Option 3)
  • Rapport: a relationship characterized by agreement, mutual understanding, or empathy that makes communication possible or easy (Option 4)


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 1413, 1415.

questions.text: Which of these is not included in personal history under psychiatry?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Food preference
 
  • The following points are included in the Personal History of Psychiatric History taking: -- Perinatal history, childhood history, Education and academic history, Obstetric history, occupational history, sexual and marital history, emotional problems in adolescents. These are included because the above categories act as stressors for development or aggravation of psychiatric disorders. 
  • Food preference is not typically included in personal history under psychiatry. While a patient's dietary habits may be relevant to their overall health and well-being, they are not typically considered a significant factor in their mental health

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 204, 212.

questions.text: Which of these is evaluated by MMSE?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Cognition
 
  • The Mini-mental state examination(MMSE) is a 30-point questionnaire that is used extensively in clinical and research settings to measure cognitive impairment.
  • It is a screening tool for dementia. It assesses cognitive functions. The total score in MMSE is 30.
  • A score less than 27 suggests Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) and less than 24 is suggestive of Dementia.



Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 201, 233, 1344.

questions.text: Which of these is not included in semantic memory?
questions.solution:
Events is Not included in Semantic memory. It is included in Episodic memory.
 
  • Semantic memory is one of the two types of declarative or explicit memory.
  • Semantic memory refers to general word knowledge that we have accumulated throughout our lives.
  • This general knowledge (facts, ideas, meaning and concepts) is intertwined in experience and dependent on culture.
  • Semantic memory is distinct from episodic memory, which is our memory of experiences and specific events that occur during our lives.
  • Episodic memory is responsible for storing and retrieving information about specific events that have occurred in our lives.




Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 116-117.

questions.text: The American Association of Mental Retardation has a new nomenclature for mental retardation:
questions.solution:
Correct Option: 3. INTELLECTUAL DISABILITY (according to DSM 5)
 
  • The new term recommended by the AAIDD is "intellectual disability," which is defined as significant limitations in both intellectual functioning and adaptive behavior, originating before the age of 18
 
  • Intellectual Disability can have the following gradings based on the IQ:-
  • Mild             - 50-69
  • Moderate    -  35-49
  • Severe         - 20-34
  • Profound     -  less than 20


Reference: American Psychiatric Association (2013) https://www.psychiatry.org/File%20Library/Psychiatrists/Practice/DSM/APA_DSM-5-Intellectual-Disability.pdf
Clinical Characteristics of Intellectual Disabilities. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK332877/

questions.text: Down syndrome is referred to as:
questions.solution:
Correct Option: 2. OLIGOPHRENIA
 
  • The term "oligophrenia" refers to a condition of limited mental ability or intellectual disability.
  • Down syndrome is a type of oligophrenia, as individuals with this condition have varying degrees of intellectual disability.


Reference: Classification of Oligophrenia and their Clinical and Pedagogical Features, Umarova Saboxon Minavvarovna, Erkinova Sarvinoz Mashrabjon qizi doi: https://cejsr.academicjournal.io/index.php/journal/article/download/741/675/1971

questions.text: A male habitual alcoholic who was 55 years old presented with unrelated conversations, trembling, and sweating. Three days prior, he had his last drink. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: 1. DELIRIUM TREMENS
The given clinical vignette describes DELIRIUM TREMENS which is a part of a wide spectrum of conditions called ALCOHOL WITHDRAWAL SYNDROME.

Benzodiazepines like Lorazepam and Oxazepam are given in treatment along with Thiamine. 


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 630.

questions.text: The following is not done in behavior therapy to increase a behavior:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Punishment. Punishment always decreases a behavior irrespective of the fact that stimulus is added or removed. To understand this concept better it’s necessary to understand CONDITIONING.
 
  • Conditioning in Psychology is a form of learning that can be of 2 types: I) CLASSICAL II) OPERANT
  • CLASSICAL CONDITIONING: It’s a form of learning in which a natural response is elicited in response to a conditioned stimulus that was previously presented with an unconditioned stimulus. This usually elicits an Involuntary response. Eg: Pavlov experiment
  • OPERANT CONDITIONING: Learning in which a particular action is elicited because it produces a punishment or reward. This usually elicits Voluntary responses. Operant conditioning works via Reinforcement or Punishment
  1. REINFORCEMENT – Can be POSITIVE (Response is followed by desired reward eg. Petrol given if driven for 100km without an accident) or NEGATIVE (Response is followed by removal of aversive stimulus eg. beeping sound removed onputting seatbelt). Reinforcement seeks to increase behavior. In both examples - the stimulus(prize/removing beeping sound) is done to increase the behavior of safe driving.
  2. PUNISHMENT – Done to decrease a behavior. Can be POSITIVE (Unpleasant stimulus given on undesired behavior eg. Fine on overspeeding) or NEGATIVE (Removal of pleasant stimulus on undesired behavior eg. Driving license/car taken away-inability to drive on overspeeding). Punishment seeks to decrease a behavior - in both scenarios -punishment is given to decrease overspeeding.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 877-882.

questions.text: The following is not part of the cognitive behavior change technique:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: CONSOLIDATION
 
  • The following question is based on the TRANSTHEORITICAL MODEL OF CHANGE.
  • This theory emphasizes the fact that the behavioural change of an individual occurs through 6 stages:
  1. PRE-CONTEMPLATION - The person denies problems and their consequences
  2. CONTEMPLATION - The person acknowledges problem but is unwilling to change
  3. PREPARATION - Committed to and planning for behaviour change
  4. ACTION - Executes plan and demonstrates a change in behaviour
  5. MAINTENANCE - new behaviours are integrated in lifestyle
  6. RELAPSE -Regression to prior behaviour. It doesn’t occur frequently.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 623.

questions.text: Two days ago, a 60-year-old man underwent heart bypass surgery. He now started to forget things and struggled to remember his family members' names and phone numbers and was agitated. Stayed awake all night only to sleep in day. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical vignette (sudden onset agitation/forgetting things/family members post surgery/hospitalization/sleep-wake issues) describes a condition called Delirium.
  • Delirium is often characterized by a sudden onset of confusion, disorientation, memory problems, and changes in behavior, such as agitation or restlessness.
  • In this case, the patient's recent heart bypass surgery is a risk factor for developing delirium. Other risk factors include older age, pre-existing cognitive impairment, and certain medications.
  • Depression and Alzheimer's disease are not the most likely causes of the patient's symptoms because they typically have a more gradual onset and are not typically associated with sudden changes in behavior.
Delirium Dementia
Onset Sudden Incidious
Conciousness Impaired normal
Course Fluctuating Progressive


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 697-701.

questions.text: Autistic disorder is not characterized by:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: VISUAL IMPAIRMENT

A few important points to remember about AUTISM SPECTRUM DISORDERS are:-
  • They are Pervasive disorders.
  • They are characterised by impairment in social interaction and communication, delay in developing and understanding peer relationships, reduced eye contact, delayed development of speech, fixated interest, and persistent preoccupation with parts of object.
  • Ambidextrous, no association with dermatoglyphics, precocious skills, mental retardation seen in 2/3 of patients. However they generally don’t have impaired cognition.{ A few one liners frequently given as stems in  MCQ questions}
 
  • This spectrum includes a number of conditions like AUTISM, RETT, ASPERGER, and HELLER.
  • AUTISM – Mental retardation isn’t present in all cases.
  • RETT SYNDROME – X linked dominant condition. MECP2 gene mutation. Seen in girls, abnormal language development, and mental retardation, regression of milestones, and normal head circumference at birth. [ V IMP TOPIC FREQUENTLY TESTED ]
  • ASPERGER SYNDROME – Common in boys.
  • HELLER SYNDROME – Common in boys. Mental retardation present, poor language development, regression of milestones and normal head circumference at birth. [ IN SHORT – SIMILAR TO RETT SYNDROME BUT COMMONLY FOUND IN BOYS]
  •  The following is a table with the most important features of each of the conditions which fall under AUTISM SPECTRUM DISORDERS.

 


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 1156.

questions.text: Select the option that is not a cognitive error/dysfunction.
questions.solution:
Correct Option: 4. THOUGHT BLOCK

The various components of Cognitive dysfunctions are:-
  • Catastrophic thinking,
  • Mind reading,
  • Personalisation,
  • Magnification,
  • Minimisation,
  • Overgeneralisation,
  • Blaming,
  • Emotional Reasoning ,
  • Arbitrarily jumping to conclusions ,
  • Polarised thinking (All or none thinking) ,
  • Mental filter
  • Disqualifying the positive.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 875.

questions.text: According to the Mental Health Act of 2017, the maximum number of days that a patient can be hospitalised voluntarily to a mental hospital is:
questions.solution:
•  According to The Mental Health Care Act, 2017 of India, Section 20(3) states that in cases of involuntary or supported admission, a person can be admitted for a period of up to 30 days, after which an extension application should be made to the Mental Health Board.
  • If a person with mental illness admitted under section 89 requires continuous admission and treatment beyond thirty days or a person with mental illness discharged under sub-section (15) of that section requires readmission within seven days of such discharge, he shall be admitted in accordance with the provisions of this section.
  • The Mental Health Board can then approve a further extension of admission based on their assessment of the person's condition. The maximum extension period allowed is 180 days.
  • In cases involving minors and persons with disabilities, the MHB is to be consulted prior to admission and the care and treatment of such persons are to be guided by their best interest.
  • The Mental Health Act also provides for the rights of patients during hospitalization, including access to legal representation, communication with family and friends, and the right to refuse treatment under certain circumstances.


Reference: The Mental health Care Act (MHCA) 2017 https://www.indiacode.nic.in/show-data?actid=AC_CEN_12_13_00024_201710_1517807327874&sectionId=6296&sectionno=90&orderno=90#:~:text=(1)%20If%20a%20person%20with,in%20accordance%20with%20the%20provisions

questions.text: While therapy session a therapist developed unconscious and conscious feelings towards the patient . What is it called?
questions.solution:
• Counter-transference, according to psychoanalytic theory, is when the therapist projects their own unresolved conflicts onto the client.
  • This can be a reaction to information the customer has discovered. Although many now see countertransference as inevitable, it can still be harmful if not handled properly.
  • Countertransference can be a result of unresolved personal issues or unresolved feelings towards previous patients. It can hinder the therapist's objectivity and ability to empathize with the patient.
  • Therefore, it is important for therapists to recognize and manage their countertransference reactions to prevent it from interfering with the therapeutic process.
  • Transference is feeling of patient towards doctors. 


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 866, 867.

questions.text: Which of the following neurotransmitter is not related to panic attacks?
questions.solution:
• Biological etiology of panic disorder is related to abnormalities in the function of a variety of neurotransmitters including serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine; 5-HT), noradrenaline (norepinephrine), gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), dopamine, and cholecystokinin.
  • Glutamate is not involved in the pathology.
  • Low levels of GABA have been associated with anxiety disorders, including panic attacks.
  • Cholecystokinin (CCK) is a neuropeptide that is involved in the regulation of appetite, anxiety, and pain. It is found in high concentrations in the amygdala, which is a brain region that is involved in fear and anxiety

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 389, 393.

choices.text: Transfer of psychic energy from the body parts to the brain

questions.text: What is counter-transference?
questions.solution:
• Counter transference occurs when a physician irrationally transfers to a patient his feelings and attitudes derived from past (childhood) experiences.
  • It is suspected whenever physician has powerful feelings of affection, protectiveness, frustration, fear, irritation, hatred or erotic excitement towards a patient; when they very much look forward to the next appointment; or when they cannot tolerate a particular patient.
  • Transference is the feeling of patient towards therapist. 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 866, 867.

questions.text: Which of the following was recently discovered as a risk factor associated with a Type D personality?
questions.solution:
• Type D personality is a personality trait characterized by negative emotions, social inhibition, and the tendency to experience stress.
  • Type D personality has been recently found to be a risk factor for coronary artery disease.
  • Type D (distressed) personality is not only a risk factor for the development of ischemic heart disease, it also leads to a worse prognosis following a myocardial infarction. 



Reference: Personality as independent predictor of long-term mortality in patients with coronary heart disease, Denollet, J et al.
The Lancet, Volume 347, Issue 8999, 417 - 421. doi: https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(96)90007-0/

questions.text: During the night, a middle-aged man laments his inability to sleep. Which of the following methods allows one to determine how long a person is actually awake or asleep?
questions.solution:
• This can be ascertained by actigraphy.
  • Actigraphy is a non-invasive method of monitoring human rest/activity cycles
  • Sleep actigraphs are helpful for identifying circadian rhythms and sleep patterns.
  • A barograph is a device used to measure atmospheric pressure, while a kymograph is a device used to measure physiological responses such as muscle contractions or heart rate.
  • Plethysmography is a method used to measure changes in blood flow or volume in different parts of the body and is not directly related to sleep monitoring.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 562.

It implies a level of awareness and understanding of their illness, as well as the potential effects of their disorder on their daily functioning.
