questions.text: Where is General Adaptation Syndrome (GAS) seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: STRESSFUL SITUATIONS
General Adaptation Syndrome describes the physiological processes the body goes through when it is under stress. It consists of 3 stages –
  • ALARM REACTION STAGE – It refers to the initial symptoms the body experiences when under stress which includes the ‘fight or flight responses’
  • RESISTANCE STAGE - After the initial stressful event and fight-flight responses body starts to repair itself. Signs of this phase are – Irritability, Frustration, Poor concentration
EXHAUSTION STAGE – It is because the body experiences chronic stress for a prolonged period of time. Signs of this phase includes – Fatigue, burnout, Depression, Anxiety, Decreased stress tolerance.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 477.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a disorder of Perception?
questions.solution:
• Illusion: Illusions are unique perceptual experiences in which information derived from "real" external stimuli results in a false perception of the thing or thing that is being stimulated.
  • Hallucination: A hallucination is a false perception of objects or events involving your senses: sight, sound, smell, touch and taste in the absence of an external stimulus
  • Delusion: Delusion is a disorder of content of thought. Its a misguided opinion/False Belief that is maintained in the face of overwhelming evidence to the contrary.
  • Depersonalization Disorder: When you have the sensation that you are looking at yourself from outside of your body, that things around you aren't real, or both, you have depersonalization-derealization disorder.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 202.

questions.text: A 50-year old patient having psychotic symptoms was started on a drug A after he had no improvement with haloperidol and thioridazine. This new drug A causes increased salivation, hyperlipidemia, and sedation. Which drug was he shifted to?
questions.solution:
The elderly schizophrenic patient has had a poor response to a trial of two drugs - haloperidol and thioridazine, which are both first-generation antipsychotics now on a new drugs experiences the mentioned symptoms. New Drug is likely Clozapine.

Indications of clozapine:
  • Treatment-resistant schizophrenia, as in this patient
  • Schizophrenia associated with suicidal tendency
Adverse effects:
  • Agranulocytosis: This is the major side effect, which is why, it is reserved for refractory schizophrenia (dose-dependent side effect)
  • Metabolic side effects: Weight gain (highest weight gain among all antipsychotics), hyperglycemia, Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Seizures (dose-independent side effect)
  • Drooling and hypersalivation
  • Myocarditis
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 3554, 3556.

questions.text: A smoker is considering giving up his habit of smoking. Which phase of motivation is he in?
questions.solution:
Pre contemplation- Patient is unaware that their behaviour is problematic
Contemplation -Recognise their problem and begin to think about changing their behaviour
Preparation- Make decisions to change their habits
Action- Individuals change their behaviour and intend to keep moving forward with this change.

Reference: KAPLAN & SADOCK’S Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page. No: 623.

questions.text: As per WHO mental health gap action plan which of the following is not a priority condition?
questions.solution:
• Priority conditions identified by the Mental health Gap action program are
  1. Depression,
  2. Schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders,
  3. Suicide,
  4. Epilepsy,
  5. Dementia,
  6. Disorders due to use of alcohol, disorders due to use of illicit drugs, and
  7. Mental disorders in children.
Reference: 
mhGAP: Mental Health Gap Action Programme: Scaling Up Care for Mental, Neurological and Substance Use Disorders. Geneva: World Health Organization; 2008. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK310851/

questions.text: Which among the following is not part of the Beck's cognitive theory on depression?
questions.solution:
• Introjection is not a part of Beck's cognitive theory of depression
Becks Cognitive triad consists of
  1. Beliefs about oneself
  2. Perceptions of surrounding
  3. Thoughts about future


Reference: KAPLAN & SADOCK’S Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page No 354-55.

choices.text: Person with cognitive decline and physical symptoms
Patient with acute psychiatric illness along with crisis
Patient with severe chronic disease and ego dysfunctioning
Person who has good motivation and control over frustration

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication for expressive psychotherapy?
questions.solution:
• Expressive psychotherapy and supportive psychotherapy are both types of therapy that can help patients, but they have different goals and techniques:
  • Supportive psychotherapy: it's is indicated for those patients in whom classic psychoanalysis or insight-oriented psychoanalytic psychotherapy is typically contraindicated- those who have poor ego strength and whose potential for decompensation is high.
  • Supportive psychotherapy plays a major etiological emphasis on external rather than intrapsychic events. particularly on stressful environmental and interpersonal influences on a severely damaged self.
  • The general aim of supportive treatment is the amelioration or relief of symptoms through behavioral or environmental restructuring within the existing psychic framework. This often means helping the patient to adapt better to problems and to live more comfortably with his or her psychopathology.
  • Expressive psychotherapy:  is indicated for patients with good motivation and control over frustration.
  • This type of therapy helps patients express themselves and cope with issues like depression, anxiety, and stress. Expressive therapy techniques include creative methods like art, dance, music, drama, and writing. The goal is to help patients learn to regulate emotions, develop social skills, and manage behaviors
Reference: KAPLAN & SADOCK’S Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page No 850- 852.

questions.text: A boy is experiencing low mood, decreased energy, and decreased interest in his surroundings. He is not taking food for the past one week. The thought sample says “| lost my head. | am dead. How can | eat?”. What is the delusion seen in this case?
questions.solution:
The type of delusion seen in this patient is a nihilistic delusion.

Nihilism refers to the delusion of the non-existence of self or parts of self. It also includes an attitude of rejection of established values or extreme skepticism regarding moral and value judgments. The patient may believe that they are going to die soon or their organs are rotting. Delusion of nihilism is often seen as a mood-congruent delusion in depression with psychotic symptoms. This patient has three major symptoms of depression — low energy, depressed mood, and lack of interest in the surroundings. However, these symptoms have to be present for a period of at least 14 days to make the diagnosis of major depressive disorder.



Reference : Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Page no 9,379-381,451-453 .

questions.text: La belle indifference is seen in:
questions.solution:
La belle indifference, often observed in conversion disorder, refers to a striking lack of concern about symptoms despite their apparent severity. Although not exclusive to conversion disorder, it is frequently associated with it.

Conversion disorder, also known as functional neurological symptom disorder or dissociative disorder, involves the sudden and temporary loss of motor or sensory function without any underlying neurological cause. These symptoms often emerge in response to psychological stress or internal conflict, leading to the hypothesis that such conflicts are “converted” into neurological symptoms. Common presentations include paresis, non-epileptic seizures (NES), blindness, or anesthesia in the limbs. A notable gait disturbance in conversion disorder is astasia-abasia, characterized by a wildly ataxic, staggering gait with irregular trunk movements and erratic arm motions. Despite these dramatic symptoms, the patient may exhibit a nonchalant attitude, as seen with la belle indifference.

In conversion disorder, patients experience a primary gain by keeping internal psychological conflicts out of conscious awareness, which instead manifest as physical symptoms. Additionally, they may achieve secondary gain by being excused from responsibilities and receiving attention or support, which might not have been accessible otherwise.


Reference : Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Page no 453-456 .

questions.text: In the Mental State Examination, (100-7=93) is done to examine which of the following mental function?
questions.solution:
The (100-7-93) test is part of the Mental Status Examination (MSE) used to evaluate a patient's concentration.

The MSE is a systematic approach to observing and describing a patient's psychological functioning at a specific moment in time, without assigning a numerical score to the patient.

The primary components of the MSE include:

1. Appearance and behavior
2. Mood and affect
3. Speech
4. Thought process and content
5. Perceptual disturbances
6. Cognition
7. Abstract reasoning
8. Insight
9. Judgment
Cognitive functioning elements assessed during the MSE consist of alertness, orientation, concentration, both short- and long-term memory, calculation, general knowledge, abstract reasoning, insight, and judgment.

Concentration can be assessed through several methods:

Counting backward from 100 by sevens (the 100-7 test)
Reciting the alphabet backward starting with Z
Naming the months of the year in reverse order, starting with December
When performing the MSE or analyzing its results, it is crucial to take into account the cultural backgrounds of both the clinician and the patient, as behavioral patterns can vary significantly across cultures. For instance, nodding in agreement in some cultures may signify disagreement in others.

The Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE), also known as Folstein's test, scores patients out of 30 and is used to assess cognitive impairment.

Note: The Mental Status Examination (MSE) and the Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) are distinct assessment tools.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing an open laparotomy. Which among the following is best as a maintenance infusion during surgery?
questions.solution:
During an open laparotomy, the goal of intraoperative fluid management is to maintain intravascular volume, tissue perfusion, and electrolyte balance.

  • Crystalloids (e.g., Ringer's lactate, normal saline) are first-line maintenance fluids. They are effective for replacing ongoing losses and maintaining hydration.

  • Colloids are generally reserved for significant hypovolemia or hypoalbuminemia.

  • Fresh frozen plasma is indicated only for coagulation factor replacement.

  • Blood is used only if there is significant blood loss or anemia.



Reference: Millers Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1513-1514.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a feature of pseudohallucination?
questions.solution:
Pseudohallucinations are hallucinatory experiences recognized by the person as unreal and usually perceived in the “inner subjective space” rather than external objective space. Key features include:

  • Vivid in nature – yes, they can be very vivid.

  • No external stimulus required – correct, they arise without external input.

  • Not under voluntary control – correct, they occur spontaneously.

  • Perceived in objective space – this is not true; pseudohallucinations are experienced internally, within the mind’s eye, unlike true hallucinations which appear in external space.


Reference: Fish's Clinical Psychopathology: Signs and Symptoms in Psychiatry-4th edition - Page no 27,28,29,30

questions.text: Which among the following dementia presents with capgras syndrome?
questions.solution:
Capgras syndrome is a delusional misidentification syndrome in which a person believes that a close relative or friend has been replaced by an imposter.

  • It is most commonly associated with Lewy body dementia due to the combination of visual hallucinations, cognitive fluctuations, and psychiatric symptoms.

  • Alzheimer’s disease can rarely show it but is less typical.

  • Frontotemporal dementia mainly presents with behavioral changes and language deficits.

  • Vascular dementia usually presents with stepwise cognitive decline and executive dysfunction, without classic delusional misidentification.



Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 21st edition Page no 192

choices.text: Physical examination, ECG, and laboratory workup were unremarkable. This is the first time she is experiencing an episode like this which lasts normally for around 20 minutes. What is the most likely diagnosis ?

questions.text: A 20-year-old lady presents with sudden palpitations, sweating, breathlessness, and a feeling like she is being choked. She had a history of a COVID-19 infection 1 year ago and fears she might die because she was positive for COVID-19. Physical examination, ECG, and laboratory workup were unremarkable. This is the first time she is experiencing an episode like this which lasts normally for around 20 minutes. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with sudden onset of intense fear or discomfort accompanied by:

  • Palpitations

  • Sweating

  • Breathlessness

  • Choking sensation

  • Fear of dying

  • Duration < 30 minutes

These are classic features of a panic attack, especially since:

  • Onset is sudden and episodic

  • No abnormalities found on physical exam or investigations

  • Associated with catastrophic misinterpretation (e.g., “I will die because I had COVID”)

    Why not others?

  • Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD): Requires a trauma with re-experiencing, avoidance, and hyperarousal, which are not described here.

  • Bipolar disorder: Involves episodes of mania and/or depression, not acute panic symptoms.

  • Depression: Persistent low mood, anhedonia, not sudden episodes of intense anxiety.


Reference:Kaplan and Sadock's Consise textbook of clinical Psychiatry 11th edition page no 394

questions.text: A 43-year-old man presents to the emergency department accompanied by police. He came to the police station accusing his daughter of wanting to kill him. The police on investigating the family and the neighbors understood that it was a false accusation. His physical examination is not remarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis here?
questions.solution:
The man is experiencing a fixed, false belief — that his daughter is trying to kill him — despite clear evidence to the contrary (investigation by police and neighbors). His physical exam is normal, and there’s no broader impairment of cognition or perception reported.

This clinical scenario is most consistent with a delusional disorder, particularly of the persecutory type.

Key Characteristics of Delusional Disorder:

  • Presence of non-bizarre delusions (e.g., being poisoned, followed, conspired against) lasting 1 month or longer.

  • Functioning is relatively preserved outside the delusion.

  • Behavior is not obviously odd or bizarre aside from the delusional content.

  • No significant hallucinations, disorganized speech, or negative symptoms as in schizophrenia.

    Other Options:

  • Illusions: Misinterpretation of a real external stimulus (e.g., mistaking a rope for a snake) — not applicable here.

  • Cotard syndrome: Nihilistic delusion — belief that one is dead, does not exist, or has lost organs/blood.

  • Hallucinations: Perceptions in the absence of external stimuli, e.g., hearing voices — not mentioned in this case.


Reference:Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry 11th edition page no 1410,1411,336

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman was brought to the psychiatric OPD by her friend. The patient claims that her boss is in love with her and stalks her. The woman's friend refutes her claims. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The woman believes her boss is in love with her, despite no evidence and clear contradiction by others (her friend). This is a classic description of Erotomania, also called De Clérambault’s syndrome.

Key Features of Erotomania:

  • A delusional belief that someone (usually of higher status) is in love with the patient.

  • The person being admired is often unaware or even disinterested.

  • Commonly seen in schizophrenia or delusional disorder (erotomanic type).

    Other Options:

  • Megalomania: Delusion of great power, wealth, or importance (not love-related).

  • Delusion of control: Belief that one’s thoughts or actions are being controlled by external forces.

  • Delusion of reference: Belief that random events or remarks refer specifically to oneself.

    Bottom Line:

  • Delusion that someone is secretly in love with the patient = Erotomania.


Reference:Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry 11th edition page no 334

questions.text: A smoker is concerned about smoking's negative effects. However, he continues to smoke since he believes he smokes less than other people and has a healthy diet. What is this process of thought known as?
questions.solution:
• Many smokers continue to support "self-exempting beliefs," also known as risk-minimizing beliefs or risk denial of smoking hazards, in spite of comprehensive tobacco control measures.
  • These ideas are used to justify or rationalize continuing to smoke despite the well-known adverse effects of tobacco use.
  • In accordance with cognitive dissonance theory, these ideas lessen the tension that results when one's knowledge of behavior is at odds with the actual behavior.


Reference: How do self-exempt beliefs affect intentions to quit smoking? An exploration of the mediating role of threat appraisal and coping appraisal Frontiers in Psychology Vol 14, 2023, DOI=10.3389/fpsyg.2023.1260561, URL=https://www.frontiersin.org/journals/psychology/articles/10.3389/fpsyg.2023.1260561

questions.text: What is a key sign of alcohol withdrawal syndrome?
questions.solution:
Key symptom in alcohol withdrawal syndrome is tremors.
Withdrawal Syndromes
Substance Features
Alcohol Hangover 
Hallucinations (usually auditory) and illusions
insomnia
Tremors/Seizures (Alcoholic seizures/Rum fits): Classic sign
Delirium tremens:
Occurs within 5 days of complete or significant abstinence from heavy alcohol drinking
Recovery occurs within 7 days
Characteristic features are clouding of consciousness, disorientation, hallucinations (mostly visual and auditory, illusions, autonomic disturbance and insomnia.



Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 630, 631.

questions.text: A guy diagnosed with alcohol dependent syndrome is admitted to the hospital by his wife after consuming 120 ml of alcohol each day for the previous 12 years. He consumed alcohol in the morning before admission. Which medication/therapy from the list below needs to be avoided?
questions.solution:
• Correct Option is 2:  DISULFIRAM
  • Disulfiram inhibits the acetaldehyde dehydrogenase enzyme thereby increasing the level of acetaldehyde in the body which causes various unpleasant symptoms like nausea hepatotoxicity etc.
  • Disulfiram is used to condition the patient to abstain from alcohol use. It should not be given until the patient has abstained from alcohol for at least 12-24 hours. A person taking Disulfiram drug should not take alcohol during the treatment as well as 14 days after stopping the drug.
  • Naltrexone  is  used to treat alcohol dependence by reducing the craving for alcohol. It is not contraindicated in this scenario and can be used as a part of the treatment plan.
  • Acamprosate  is  used to reduce the symptoms of alcohol withdrawal and prevent relapse in alcohol dependence. It is not contraindicated in this scenario and can be used as a part of the treatment plan.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 638, 639.

questions.text: Which is the most effective drug used for smoking cessation?
questions.solution:
• Vareniciline is an α4β2 partial agonist.
  • It is the most effective monotherapy for smoking cessation.
  • Side effects include Increased suicidal thoughts and depressive/psychotic symptoms.
  • It is more effective than other smoking cessation medications such as bupropion and nicotine replacement therapy (nicotine gum, patches, lozenges, etc.) and has been shown to increase the chances of successfully quitting smoking by up to three times compared to placebo
  • It is started 1 week before the target date of cessation and therapy is continued for 12 weeks. 
  • Side effect- Suicidal thoughts 


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 134.
Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 684

questions.text: Following repeated appeals from his family, a chronic alcoholic male, age 53, made an effort to cut down on his drinking. After developing uneasiness, he was sent to the hospital on day three with altered sensory perception, confusion, anger, paranoid delusions, and visual hallucinations. Which of these is your likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The most severe type of ethanol withdrawal, known as delirium tremens, is characterised by altered mental status (generalised disorientation), sympathetic overdrive (autonomic hyperactivity), and circulatory collapse.
  • The symptoms of mild alcohol withdrawal include trembling, anxiety, nausea, vomiting, and insomnia.
  • Visual and auditory hallucinations, whole-body tremor, vomiting, diaphoresis, and hypertension are the main signs and symptoms of alcohol withdrawal.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 630. 631.

questions.text: A 50y old male started alcohol at 20 years, presently taking 3 quarters daily over 30 years, now complains that he gets the kick in 1 quarter, diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Diagnosis is Reverse tolerance.
  • When a heavy drinker develops liver damage, the liver no longer generates as much of the enzymes required to break down alcohol in the body as it once did, resulting in reverse tolerance.
  • Reverse tolerance occurs when the body becomes more sensitive to the effects of a drug over time, even with lower doses
  • The Mellanby effect is the idea that people experience more intense alcohol intoxication symptoms when their blood alcohol concentration (BAC) is increasing than when it's decreasing even if the BAC is same in both cases.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 617

questions.text: Identify the drug of choice for substitution therapy in a case of heroin dependence:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: METHADONE

Long acting opioids like METHADONE used for heroin detoxification as well as long term maintenance therapy.




Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 660, 663.

choices.text: Requirement of higher dose of the substance to get the same effect
Physical and psychological reactions when a person withdraws from using the substance
Substance becomes more important than anything else in life
Usage of substance below what one intended to use

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic of dependence?
questions.solution:
The incorrect option is Option 4. Usage of substance below what one intended to use 

Criteria:
  1. Usage of substance beyond what one intended to use is Loss of control .
  2. Requirement of higher dose of the substance to get the same effect-Tolerance
  3. Physical and psychological reactions when a person withdraws from using the substance -Withdrawal
  4. Substance becomes more important than anything else in life-Salience
  5. Intense physiological urge to use the substance -Craving
  6. Harmful use 
3 or more out of six features for more than or equal to 1 month indicates substance dependence.



Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 616, 617.

questions.text: Drug-addicted 16-year-old boy exhibits synesthesia- which allows noises to be seen while colors are heared. Which of the following is the most likely agent responsible for drug abuse?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: LSD

The given clinical vignette describes the misuse of LSD
The following are the important points to kept in mind regarding the use of LSD:-
  • Visual Hallucinations
  • Euphoria
  • Synesthesia – It’s a condition where there is anomalous blending of senses. Stimulation of one modality produces sensation in a different modality ( as mentioned in the given question)
  • Dysphoria panic tachycardia hypertension ( in short stimulation)

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 653.

questions.text: Paranoid Psychosis with cocaine is seen because of -
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: INTOXICATION
The following are the features of cocaine intoxication:-
  • Chest pain, agitation, euphoria ,tachycardia, hypertension, angina ,sudden cardiac death
  • Seizures
  • Mydriasis
  • Tactile hallucinations – MAGNAN BUGS
  • Paranoid psychosis
  • Perforated nasal septum
  • Bruxism, black discoloration of teeth
  • Brain Haemorrhage  { common causes of brain haemorrhage in adults include – trauma > AV malformation > Cocaine }
THE FOLLOWING TABLE IS TO INCORPORATE THE KEY POINTS AND FEATURES OF INTOXICATION AND WITHDRAWAL OF SUBSTANCES WHICH ARE FREQUENTLY ASKED IN EXAMS:-




Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 672, 673.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the Emergency department by his relatives. He was having respiratory depression and relatives suspected him to have overdosed with Opioids. Which drug is best used in managing such a case?
questions.solution:
The answer to the above question is Naloxone. It is an opioid antagonist given intravenously to reverse the effects of opioid toxicity. 
 
  • Naloxone is an opioid antagonist and is the first-line treatment for opioid overdose, particularly in cases of respiratory depression. It works by binding to opioid receptors in the brain, reversing the effects of opioids, including respiratory depression, sedation, and hypotension. It can be administered intramuscularly or intravenously and can rapidly reverse the life-threatening effects of opioid overdose.

Other options:
 

  • Naltrexone: (Option 1)- Although naltrexone is also an opioid antagonist, it is administered orally. Hence it is not preferred in emergency management of opioid overdose. 

  • Flumazenil: (Option 3) This is a benzodiazepine antagonist, used to reverse the effects of benzodiazepine overdose, not opioids. It would not be effective in managing an opioid overdose.

  • Clonidine: (Option 4) This is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist, used in the management of opioid withdrawal symptoms, but it is not effective for reversing respiratory depression caused by opioid overdose.




Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 383.

questions.text:
A 52 year old chronic alcoholic for last many years with daily drinking habits, comes to emergency with H/O Seizures auditory hallucinations and 2° dilutions. His last drink was 2 days back. Choose the most appropriate management:
I. Diazepam 
II. Naltrexone
III. Inj. Thiamine 
IV. Inj. Flupenthixol
questions.solution:
Scenario is suggestive of Delirium tremens.
 
  • Naltrexone (anti-craving) is given after withdrawal is over.
  • Flupenthixol is long-acting antipsychotic depot injection not required in this case.
  • Drug of choice for alcohol withdrawal is Benzodiazepines 
  • Thiamine is given to prevent Wernicke's encephalopathy.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3561, 3562.

Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page no 631, 632.

questions.text: A patient with chronic alcohol use (around 1 bottle of whisky daily), stopped consuming alcohol for 2 days. He was brought to emergency, on investigation, LFTs were deranged. Which of the following should be given for detoxification?
questions.solution:
The correct option for detoxification in a patient with chronic alcohol use and deranged LFT after stopping alcohol for 2 days is Lorazepam, which is option 3.
  • Lorazepam is particularly useful in patients with liver disease, as it is metabolized by glucuronidation rather than by the liver, which reduces the risk of toxicity.

Other options:
 
  • Option 1: Haloperidol is an antipsychotic medication that is not used for detoxification in alcohol-dependent patients. It is used to treat psychotic disorders and agitation.
 
  • Option 2 : Chlordiazepoxide, is a benzodiazepine that is also commonly used for alcohol detoxification. However, in patients with liver disease, it can accumulate and cause toxicity, so lorazepam is preferred.
 
  • Option 4 : Diazepam, is another benzodiazepine that is used for alcohol detoxification. However, it is metabolized by the liver, so it may not be the best choice for patients with liver disease.

Therefore, based on the given scenario, Lorazepam is the best choice for detoxification in this patient.



Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 311, 342-345.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presents with confusion and ataxia. He was unable to move his eye outwards.  On examination, there is 6th nerve palsy. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A chronic alcoholic presents with the classic triad of:
  • Confusion
  • Ataxia
  • Ophthalmoplegia
This is suggestive of Wernicke's encephalopathy caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2525, 3561.

questions.text: HEADSSS assessment is used to which group of patients?
questions.solution:
HEADSSS-Home, Education, Activities, Drugs, Sexuality, Suicide, Safety.
It is done in adolescents to determine early symptoms of mental disorder and functional impairment among major life domains.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th Edition, Page. No: 186.

questions.text: A patient stopped alcohol consumption for 3 days and presented with irritability, disorientation, paranoid delusions, agitation, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with acute onset of confusion, agitation, hallucinations, and autonomic hyperactivity after cessation of alcohol for 2–5 days.

Key features of Delirium Tremens (DT):

  • Occurs 48–96 hours after alcohol withdrawal

  • Symptoms:

    • Severe agitation and restlessness

    • Disorientation and altered sensorium

    • Visual hallucinations (often terrifying)

    • Tachycardia, hypertension, diaphoresis

    • Paranoid delusions

Other options:

  • Wernicke’s encephalopathy: Triad of ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, confusion; usually due to thiamine deficiency

  • Alcohol-induced psychosis: Occurs during chronic alcohol use; hallucinations are usually auditory

  • Korsakoff psychosis: Chronic condition with memory deficits and confabulation, not acute agitation

questions.text: A young boy presents to the emergency department after being at a party. Within minutes, he had started to feel his heart race, had profuse sweating and tremors, and was rushed to the hospital. He also reports seeing red halos while listening to music. Which of the following drugs did he most likely consume?
questions.solution:
• The boy developed rapid-onset symptoms including palpitations, profuse sweating, tremors, and visual hallucinations (red halos, seeing patterns with music) shortly after a party.

  • These features are characteristic of hallucinogen intoxication, particularly LSD, which causes visual and sensory distortions, tachycardia, and autonomic stimulation.

  • Other options:

    • Cannabis: Causes euphoria, altered perception, mild tachycardia, but visual hallucinations are uncommon.

    • Amphetamines: Cause stimulation, tachycardia, hypertension, but not vivid visual hallucinations.

    • Cocaine: Causes sympathomimetic symptoms (tachycardia, hypertension, sweating), but hallucinations are less common and usually tactile rather than visual.

High-yield point: Visual hallucinations, especially seeing colors or halos with music, + acute sympathetic overdrive → LSD intoxication.

questions.text:
Which of the following is used to define dependence?
A. Strong desire to use the drug
B. Priority to use drugs other than any other activity
C. Increased tolerance
D. Persistent use of drugs despite knowing the harmful effects
questions.solution:
According to ICD-11, substance dependence is characterized by the following:
 
  • A strong internal compulsion to use the substance, which the individual finds difficult to control.
  • A higher priority is given to substance use over other activities.
  • Continued substance use despite the knowledge of its harmful effects.
  • The subjective experience of cravings or urges to use the substance.
  • Tolerance develops, requiring larger amounts of the substance to achieve the same effect.
  • Withdrawal symptoms occur upon reducing or stopping substance use.

The diagnosis of dependence can be made if these symptoms persist for at least three months.



Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page no 270.

questions.text: The tactile hallucinations seen in cases of chronic cocaine intoxication is?
questions.solution:
Formication, the sensation of insects crawling under the skin, is a common feature of cocaine abuse and is also known as Magnan‘s symptom or cocaine bugs. Acute stimulant intoxication can manifest with symptoms such as agitation, irritability, aggression, and increased psychomotor activity. Physical examination may reveal tachycardia, hypertension, and mydriasis. When stimulants like cocaine cause psychotic symptoms, including delusions and hallucinations, it is classified as stimulant-induced psychotic disorder. Paranoid delusions and hallucinations are key features of stimulant-induced psychosis, with tactile hallucinations like formication specifically associated with cocaine use. The occurrence of these symptoms depends on the dose and duration of drug use, meaning not all patients will experience them. Cocaine-induced psychotic disorders are more commonly observed in intravenous users and those who smoke crack, a highly potent and addictive form of cocaine



Reference : Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Page no 302-305 .

questions.text: What is the most common symptom of cannabis intake?
questions.solution:
The most frequently reported symptom of cannabis consumption is a dream-like state.

Effects of Cannabis Use:
After consuming cannabis, users often experience:
Mild euphoria
Relaxation
Changes in perception
Cognitive effects may involve:
Impaired short-term memory Reduced attention
Users frequently find themselves in a pleasant, dreamy state, which can make it difficult to maintain focused, goal-directed thinking.

Withdrawal Symptoms:
When individuals stop using cannabis, they may encounter withdrawal symptoms, which can include:
Anxiety
Decreased appetite
Depressed mood

questions.text: A patient stopped alcohol consumption for 3 days and presented with irritability, disorientation, paranoid delusions, agitation, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms typical of delirium tremens (DTs), which is a severe manifestation of alcohol withdrawal. The hallmark features include irritability, disorientation, paranoid delusions, agitation, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium. DTs generally occur 48 to 72 hours after the cessation of alcohol consumption, which aligns with the patient's history of stopping alcohol intake 3 days ago. It is a medical emergency that requires immediate treatment.

Delirium Tremens
Key Features:
- Altered Sensorium: Disorientation and confusion.
-Hallucinations: Visual and tactile hallucinations are common.
-Autonomic Hyperactivity: Symptoms include tachycardia, hypertension, sweating, fever, and anxiety.
-Psychomotor Fluctuations: Ranges from agitation to lethargy.
-Altered Sleep-Wake Cycle: Disturbances in normal sleep patterns.

Other options

1. Wernicke's Encephalopathy:
Cause: Thiamine deficiency related to alcohol abuse.
Symptoms: [GOA]
- Global confusion.
- Ocular abnormalities (nystagmus, gaze palsy).
- Ataxia.
- Treatment: Thiamine supplementation.

This patient lacks ataxia and ophthalmoplegia, which are essential components of Wernicke’s encephalopathy. Moreover, it is typically seen in chronic alcoholics with poor nutritional intake, not necessarily in the early stages of alcohol withdrawal.

2. Korsakoff's Psychosis:
Korsakoff psychosis develops as a result of long-term thiamine deficiency and is characterized by chronic memory disturbances, not acute withdrawal symptoms like those seen in this patient.
Symptoms of Korsakoff's Psychosis:
- Impaired recent memory.
- Anterograde amnesia.
- Confabulation.
- Characteristic: Intact sensorium.

3. Alcohol-Induced Psychosis:
The patient's symptoms are more consistent with withdrawal rather than intoxication. Alcohol-induced psychosis typically manifests during or immediately after alcohol consumption, not several days after cessation
Characteristics: Auditory hallucinations and paranoid delusions in the context of heavy drinking.

questions.text: A man arrives with a background of strange blinking and groaning. He asserts that he is powerless over his symptoms, which have been occurring more frequently lately. His social life has started to suffer as a result. Which of the following drugs should he be given?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario suggests motor and vocal tics associated with Tourette's disorder.
  • Antipsychotics (haloperidol, risperidone) are used in this condition.
  • Risperidone is an antipsychotic medication that has been found to be effective in reducing the severity and frequency of tics in individuals with Tourette's syndrome.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 1197-1199.

questions.text: A mood stabilizer was controlling a male patient with bipolar disorder who had previously experienced 5 bouts of mania and 1 episode of depression in the previous 8 years. However, manic symptoms started to develop as he tapered off the medication. Which of the subsequent actions needs to be taken to increase drug compliance?
questions.solution:
• An evidence-based therapy intervention for patients/loved ones that offer knowledge to better understand and manage sickness is known as psychoeducation (a portmanteau of psychological education).
  • Psychoeducation is most frequently associated with serious mental illnesses like psychosis, clinical depression, anxiety disorders, etc.
  • Patients and family members who receive psychoeducation are taught problem-solving and communication techniques, and they are given information and tools in a compassionate setting. Results from many studies show that psychoeducation enhances rehabilitation, decreases relapse rates, and benefits families.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 1271, 1272.

questions.text: A young patient was admitted to hospital with acute psychosis. He wakes up and asks the nurse to call his wife who was there in the same room in the same area. Upon seeing her, he started beating her thinking that it was nurse who was masquerading as his wife. He also said she was the same nurse who gave her wrong medication 2 days back as well to make him ill, because she wanted to harm him but who was actually his wife. What syndrome he is suffering from?
questions.solution:
• The patient has Capgras syndrome, in accordance with the description provided (the wife, a fa,iliar person has been substituted with the nurse, an impostor).
  • The delusion in Capgras syndrome is the conviction that an impostor has taken the place of a familiar individual
 
  • In Frégoli’s syndrome, a person believes that a familiar person (such as a spouse or loved one) is being impersonated by others, often as part of a delusion that someone is taking on multiple appearances to deceive or harm them.
.



Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 319, 321.

questions.text:
After starting their new job, an IT professional feels guilty, helpless, and unable to focus. His symptoms began three years ago, when he first enrolled in college.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The most likely diagnosis for the IT professional is Dysthymia, which is a type of chronic depression that lasts for at least two years.
  • The symptoms of Dysthymia are similar to those of major depression, but they are less severe and often go unnoticed. The individual may feel guilty, helpless, and unable to focus, which can affect their ability to function at work and in their personal life.
  • Dysthymia is highly indicative when a melancholy mood lasts for the majority of the day and is usually always present together with accompanying emotions of inadequacy, guilt, impatience, and anger; withdrawal from society; loss of interest; and inactivity and lack of production.
  • Adjustment disorder  is a type of stress-related disorder that occurs when an individual has difficulty coping with a stressful life event, such as starting a new job. However, the duration of symptoms in adjustment disorder is typically less than six months, which is not consistent with the three-year duration of symptoms in this case.
  • Cyclothymic disorder  is a type of mood disorder that involves cycling between periods of hypomania and mild depression. However, the symptoms described in this case are not consistent with cyclothymic disorder, as there is no mention of hypomanic episodes.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 363, 365.

questions.text:
A male 22-year-old complains to you in your office about frequently checking doors even though they are locked. He is troubled by this reality. His obsessive-compulsive condition is subsequently identified. Take into account the following claims:
a.  Sublimation - the defense mechanisms involved
b. SSRIs are the drug of choice
c. Risperidone may be used in SSRI-resistant cases to augment the response
d. Systemic desensitization is the psychotherapy of choice

Which of the above are correct statements?
questions.solution:
The correct option is 2: b & c
The given clinical scenario describes a condition called OCD.

Important points about OCD.
  • The common symptoms seen in OCD are Contamination (most common) > Pathological doubt > Intrusive thoughts > Symmetry
  • Defense Mechanisms in OCD – Displacement, Undoing, Reaction formation, Inhibition, Isolation of affect
  • Drug of choice - SSRI. Atypical antipsychotics (like risperidone) can be given in resistant cases
  • Psychotherapy of Choice -  Exposure and Response prevention which is a form of CBT.



Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 424-426.

questions.text: According to the ICD-10 revision for establishing a diagnosis of mania, the symptoms should persist for at least how many weeks?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. 1 week 
 
  • According to ICD 10, symptoms should persist for at-least 7 days to diagnose mania and for "several days" to diagnose hypomania.
  • A manic episode is a distinct period of an abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood lasting for at least 1 week or less if a patient must be hospitalized.
  • A hypomanic episode lasts at least 4 days and is similar to a manic episode except that it is not sufficiently severe to cause impairment in social or occupational functioning, and no psychotic features are present


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 348.

questions.text: What is the preferred evidence-based psychological treatment for depression?
questions.solution:
• Cognitive Behaviour Therapy is focussed on correction of biased interpretations which had lead to a maladaptive emotional distress. Thus the emphasis is on a person's views of self, world and future( the "cognitive triad").
  • Its a short-term lasting about 25 weeks, structured therapy using active collaboration between patient and therapist to achieve goals of therapy oriented towards current problems and their resolution.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 372.

questions.text: A patient who has experienced RTA in the past two months complains of having accident-related dreams. Every time he goes there, he can picture the exact same sight. So, he is reluctant to return to the scene of the accident. Determine the kind of condition he may be experiencing?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. PTSD

The given clinical vignette describes the condition - PTSD
A few important points about PTSD:-
  • Timeline – more than 1 month
  • 4 important features: - Hyperarousal, Avoidance of associated stimulus, Reexperiencing the events through flashbacks and dreams (Important buzzword usually given in clinical vignette), Distress and fear.
  • Management- SSRI, CBT, EMDR


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page no 429, 172-174.

questions.text: All of the following are a habit disorder, with one exception that is
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: TEMPER TANTRUMS
 
  • Habit Disorders include a broad spectrum of conditions which include repetitive behaviors that are distressing and cause significant functional decline. These include Tic Disorder, Body-focused repetitive behaviors like thumb-sucking nail-biting trichotillomania, as well as bruxism, and OCD.
  • However, Temper tantrums on the contrary are outburst of emotions, generally intermittent and don’t really cause any significant functional decline. It's not considered a habit disorder.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 294.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man has been worried about his wife having an affair with his employer for the past two months. He believes that his friend is participating from abroad and offering technical assistance. He believes that others criticise him. Despite the efforts of his friends to persuade him, he is not at all persuaded. He is otherwise healthy; he doesn't exhibit any abnormal behaviour or thought disorders. The following is the likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: PERSISTENT DELUSION DISORDER
The given clinical vignette describes a condition called OTHELLO SYNDROME or Delusion of Jealousy. (Very frequently tested in exams)
A few important points, terms and syndromes to remember about Delusion:-
  • Timeline- More than or equal to 1 month
  • It’s a fixed, firm and false belief.
  • Apart from that particular delusion all order fields of life and functioning remains unaffected. ( VVV IMP)
  • Most common delusion - Delusion of Persecution
  • FOLIE A DEUX - Shared delusion where a person develops delusion after staying around a person having delusion.
  • DECLEREMBAUT SYNDROME - Erotomania [Imp clinical scenario frequently tested - The person generally a woman feels that the celebrity or a person of higher social profile loves her.]
  • OTHELLO SYNDROME
  • COTARD SYNDROME - Nihilistic Delusion-[Imp clinical scenario frequently tested- The person feels that his intestines are rotting and the world is ending.]
  • EKBOM SYNDROME – Delusional Parasitosis – Person constantly feels that he is infested with parasites.
  • CAPGRAS - FAMILY SEEMS LIKE STRANGER
  • FREGOLI- STRANGER SEEMS LIKE FAMILY
[CAPGRAS- FREGOLI: TRICK TO REMEMBER - A person cannot recognize his family members once they start wearing caps - CAPGRAS]


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 334.

questions.text: Alcohol paranoia is linked to:
questions.solution:
• Alcoholic paranoia is an alcohol-induced psychotic disorder
  • It is characterized by delusions (mostly of persecution/jealousy/reference) Eg. a drunkard husband having the delusion that his wife is having an extramarital affair.
  • Auditory hallucinations may also be seen occasionally

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 337.

choices.text: Stop the current antidepressants and add mood stabiliser

questions.text: When a woman with h/o depression visited the OPD, imipramine was administered. A week later, passers by complained that she was talking too much and experiencing hallucinations. What tips do you have for follow-up
questions.solution:
• If a person is identified to be at risk for developing either mania or hypomania when taking tricyclics (like given in clinical scenario - talking too much/experiencing hallucinations), the first step would be to stop the current antidepressant.
  • Mania and hypomania require specialized treatment with mood stabilizers.
  • Tricyclic antidepressants can cause profound changes in mood and can be dangerous/exacerbate the manic episode in vulnerable individuals.
  • By stopping the current antidepressant, a person is taking the first step in avoiding these potentially dangerous effects.
  • The ideal management would be to stop the anti depressant followed by adding mood stabiliser along with second generation anti- psychotic. Hence the best answer would be option 1


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 375, 378, 379.

questions.text: Except for ________, each of the following is a positive prognostic indicator for schizophrenia.
questions.solution:
Insidious onset of symptoms is not a good prognostic factor for Schizophrenia.






Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 318.

questions.text: A male patient recently lost his work (1 week ago), which caused him to become agitated and depressed. His mood got worse when he pondered about his employment and the future. He was more irritable around the people in his house, but on occasion, he went to the movies with his friends and was able to enjoy himself. What can be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient is most probably suffering from Adjustment disorder.
  • Since depression is persistent, it can be ruled out in this instance because the patient is able to have fun.
  • The symptoms of generalized anxiety disorder must last for at least six months.
  • Adjustment disorder Occurs when a person has a great amount of trouble coping with major psychosocial stressors.
  • Typically, symptoms start 2 weeks to 3 months after the incident and go away within 6 months.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 446-448.

questions.text: What is the appropriate medical management for a psychotic patient who developed voluntary, meaningless movements and was once seen standing stationary for hours with waxy flexibility?
questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from Catatonia.

The drug of choice for Catatonia is benzodiazepines preferably Intramuscular Lorazepam.

Catatonia:
  • A behavioral disorder and psycho-motor immobility.
  • Frequently connected with schizophrenia
  • Types:
    • 1. Catatonia along with other illnesses
    • ii. Catatonia brought on by other medical conditions
    • iii. Unspecific Catatonia

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page no 671.

questions.text:
A hysterical female patient was exhaling rapidly. She experienced carpopedal spasm. pH is 7.52, CO2 is 20, and HCO3 is 24 on ABG.
What is the abnormal acid-base condition?
questions.solution:
• This patient is suffering from respiratory alkalosis.
  • Decreased H+ ion concentration brought on by alkalosis causes more albumin to bind to calcium.
  • This results in lower levels of free calcium, which causes hypocalcemia and tetany in this patient.
Trick:- ROMS for pH and pCO2
Respiratory Opposite 
Metabolic Same



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 358.

questions.text: Which illness falls under the category of formal thought disorder?
questions.solution:
• Types of thought disorder include
  1. derailment,
  2. Pressured speech, 
  3. poverty of speech,
  4. Tangentiality,
  5. Verbigeration and
  6. Thought blocking.

questions.text: The patient, a 16-year-old female, had overfamiliarity, a struggle with thoughts, a high mood, heightened sexual drive, and pseudo hallucinations. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
• Mania is a mental illness that results in unjustified euphoria, extremely intense feelings, hyperactivity, and delusions.
  • A typical bipolar disorder symptom is mania (or manic episodes). For a number of reasons, mania can be a dangerous condition.
  • During having a manic episode, some people may not eat or sleep.
  • Hypomania, is a less severe form of mania characterized by similar symptoms but with less intensity and duration.  
  • Cyclothymia, is a mood disorder characterized by chronic fluctuations in mood that are not severe enough to meet the criteria for bipolar disorder.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 292, 293, 348, 358.

questions.text:
An extremely depressed patient had ECT.  The patient received thiopental and succinylcholine from the anesthesiologist. 
How did these substances affect the patient?
questions.solution:
• The two drugs given by the anaesthetist are used for providing general anaesthesia and muscle relaxation to the patient.
 
  • Thiopentone is an anaesthetic agent while succinylcholine acts as a muscle relaxation. These drugs are given by an anaesthetist in modified Electroconvulsive Therapy which is the only legal form of ECT acceptable nowadays.

questions.text: Which disease is covered in the ICD 11 category of body-focused repetitive behaviour?
questions.solution:
The correct option is (4) Trichotillomania.
 
  • Body-focused repetitive behavior (BFRB) is an umbrella name for impulse control behaviors involving damage to one's physical appearance or causing physical injury.
  • These disorders include 
  1. Trichotillomania(hair pulling)
  2. Skin-Picking (Dermatotillomania)
  3. Onychophagia (nail biting).

Reference: Grant, Jon E, and Dan J Stein. “Body-focused repetitive behavior disorders in ICD-11.” Revista brasileira de psiquiatria (Sao Paulo, Brazil : 1999) vol. 36 Suppl 1 (2014): 59-64. doi:10.1590/1516-4446-2013-1228 
Kaplan and Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 286.

questions.text: What feature does somatic passivity possess?
questions.solution:
• Schneider's first rank symptoms of Schizophrenia are:
  1. Hallucinations,
  2. Delusional perception,
  3. Thought alienations and
  4. Passivity phenomenon (Somatic passivity).

questions.text: Which combination is present in type II bipolar disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Hypomania + depression

Bipolar disorder or manic depressive psychosis is characterized by unpredictable swings in mood from mania (or hypomania) to depression at different times and in the intervening period, the patient may be normal.

Type I bipolar disorder 
Characterized by a clinical course of 2:1 manic (severe) episodes (which last for at least one week) and sometimes major (severe) depressive episodes (however may not be present and not necessary for diagnosis)

Type II bipolar disorder 
Combination of Hypomania (a milder form of mania lasting for 4 days) and depressive episodes (necessary for diagnosis).


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 356, 364.

choices.text: TCAs are better than MAO and SSRI for treatment

Marked fatigue and heaviness in the body

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics does not describe atypical depression?
questions.solution:
• Patients with typical depression are usually treated with tricyclic antidepressants (such as imipramine) and electroconvulsive therapy (ECT), and they generally benefit from these treatments.
  • However, patients with atypical depression do not typically benefit from traditional treatments of depression, and they often require specific therapies such as monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs), which are not typically used as a first line of treatment.
Other features of Atypical depression-
  • Increased appetite, weight and sleep.
  • Mood reactivity is present
  • Extreme sensitivity to interpersonal rejection
  • Leaden paralysis. 


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page no 382, 390, 572.

questions.text: A patient lives alone, is emotionally cold, shy, and prefers social isolation. They also lack delusions and hallucinations. Which personality disorder does this patient have?
questions.solution:
• Option (1) > Option (4)
  • People having Antisocial personality disorder also have impulsive, irresponsible, and often criminal behavior.
  • People with Schizoid personality disorder are loners who prefer solitary activities and rarely express strong emotions. They tend to be distant, detached, and indifferent to social relationships



Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 746-750.

questions.text: What can be a poor prognostic factor for a patient of Schizophrenia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: INSIDUOUS ONSET

The following table depicts the different prognostic factors of Schizophrenia:-


A few most important points to remember about Schizophrenia are:-
  • Timeline: - Onset for more than or equal to 6 months with more than 1 month of active symptoms over the past 6 months.
  • It is a profound functional impairment characterised by positive negative cognitive symptoms.
  • Positive – hallucinations delusions bizarre behaviour
  • Negative – Anhedonia apathy diminished functioning
  • Cognitive – diminished memory and attention, reduced ability to understand
  • Diagnosis – Requires ≥ 2 active symptoms with ≥ 1 of DELUSION, HALLUCINATION, and DISORGANISED SPEECH. The active symptoms include Delusion, Hallucination, Disorganised speech, Disorganised or catatonic behaviour, negative symptoms.
  • It is characterised by increased suicidal tendencies.
  • Associated with increased serotonergic activity.
  • Brain imaging findings may show ventriculomegaly.
  • Subtypes :-
    1. PARANOID – Associated with delusion and hallucination
    2. CATATONIC – Motor function disturbance
    3. SIMPLE 
    4. HEBEPHRENIC – disorganised behaviour and poor contact with reality.
  • Treatment – Atypical antipsychotics like Risperidone

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 318.

questions.text: The following statement regarding anorexia nervosa is not correct:

questions.text: For no obvious reason, a woman washes her hands at least 40 times every day. What should be included in her cognitive behavioral therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: EXPOSURE AND RESPONSE PREVENTION
 
  • The given clinical vignette describes the clinical condition called OCD – Obsessive Compulsive Disorder.
  • Management of OCD: DOC – SSRI; Antipsychotic drugs like Clomipramine, Risperidone, Aripiprazole can be given in SSRI Resistant cases. Psychotherapy of choice- CBT
  •  Exposure and response prevention should commonly be included in the cognitive behavorial therapy in OCD.
Some important points to remember among different psychotherapies which are frequently asked in exams:-

•            PTSD --- EMDR (Eye Movement Desensitisation and Reprocessing); however the most effective therapy is CBT.
•            OCD ---- CBT; ERP (Exposure Response Prevention)
•            Phobia—Systemic Desensitisation – (It includes 3 steps: - Desensitisation of stimulus, Relaxation training, graded exposure)
•            Substance Use Disorder – Motivational Interviewing]

{Regarding MCQ frequently asked PTSD – EMDR (4 letters); OCD – CBT, ERP (3 letters)} --- Trick to remember it fast.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 425.

questions.text: Which is an exception to Bleuler's criteria for schizophrenia ?
