questions.text: 32 y old female with history of bipolar disorder currently on 750mg lithium for the past one year and has no episodes is in her third trimester of pregnancy. what would be the next step of management?
questions.solution:
Lithium is mood stabliser with narrow therapeutic index used to treat Bipolar disorder. Since the woman is currently asymtomatic on current dose of lithium for the past one year she can be under regular follow up with reduction in dose of lithium.
Patient is advised to monitor blood lithium levels upto week 34 and then weekly monitoring upto delivery. It is recommended to stop lithium during active labour and restart after delivery.

Reference: William’s Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page. No- 153, 1146.

questions.text: A 20-year-old survivor of a terrorist attack that happened 2 weeks ago comes to the psychiatry OPD with complaints of persistent flashbacks about the incident. She has been unable to sleep properly and is avoiding going to crowded places. She is no longer interested in doing activities with her friends. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient developed symptoms 2 weeks after a traumatic event:

  • Flashbacks (re-experiencing)

  • Avoidance of triggers

  • Sleep disturbance

  • Loss of interest

Key distinction between Acute Stress Disorder (ASD) and PTSD:

  • ASD: Symptoms occur 3 days to 4 weeks after trauma.

  • PTSD: Symptoms persist beyond 1 month.

Since this patient’s symptoms are within 2 weeks of the trauma, the diagnosis is Acute Stress Disorder. If symptoms persist beyond 4 weeks, it may evolve into PTSD.

questions.text: A 25 year old male has thoughts of cutting his fingers, he plans and imagines doing it but never actually does it. He says that his sister is influencing his thoughts. His mother reports that he has no sister, and he talks to someone who is not present in the room. Which of the following is the cause?
questions.solution:
Thought Insertion: A type of delusion where the individual believes that thoughts are being implanted by someone else.
Schneider's First-Rank Symptoms: These are critical in diagnosing schizophrenia and include:
1. Hallucinations:
Audible Thoughts: Hearing one's thoughts spoken aloud.
Voices Arguing: Hearing multiple voices discussing or arguing about the person.
Voices Commenting: Hearing voices that comment on the person's actions.
2. Thought Phenomena:
Thought Withdrawal: Belief that thoughts are being removed from one's mind.
Thought Broadcasting: The belief that one's thoughts are accessible to others.
3. Made Phenomena:
Made Affect: Feelings imposed by an external source.
Made Impulses: External control over impulses or drives.
Made Volitional Acts: Actions controlled by an external agent.
4. Delusional Perception: Misinterpretation of normal perceptions leading to delusions.
5. Somatic Passivity: Experiencing bodily sensations imposed by an external force.

choices.text: Rapid cyclers are more common in women
Rapid cyclers need at least two distinct episodes per year
Rapid cycles in BPAD are seen concomitantly with hypothyroidism and diabetes
Drug of choice for prophylaxis of rapid cycling disorder is Valproate

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding Rapid cyclers?
questions.solution:
• Rapid cycling disorder is diagnosed when the patient has a combination of 4 or more bipolar episodes within the last 12 months.
  • Two separate episodes can be demarcated from one another by either switch in polarity or full/partial remission for at least 2 months.
  • Possible risk factors for rapid cycling disorder include female patients, diabetes, childhood abuse or family trauma, and alcoholism or substance abuse.
  • The drug of choice for prophylaxis of rapid cycling disorder is Valproate.
Reference: KAPLAN & SADOCK’S Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page No 360.

questions.text: You see a middle-aged man presenting to the psychiatry OPD who reports aliens have been speaking to him and telling him to kill his relatives over the past 7 months. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has experienced auditory hallucinations for the past 7 months, making the diagnosis of schizophrenia more likely among the available options.

Diagnostic Criteria for Schizophrenia (DSM-5):
1. The DSM-5 requires a total duration of at least 6 months for a schizophrenia diagnosis.

2. Within this 6-month timeframe, there must be at least 1 month of overt psychotic symptoms, with 2 or more of the following present. At least one of these symptoms must be a delusion, hallucination, or disorganized speech:

a. Delusion
b. Hallucination
c. Disorganized speech (or formal thought disorder)
d. Disorganized behavior
e. Affective flattening or other negative symptoms

It is essential to exclude mood disorders and substance abuse before confirming the diagnosis.
In this case, the individual has sought medical attention due to auditory hallucinations of aliens instructing him to harm his relatives, which further supports the possibility of schizophrenia.

questions.text: A 38-year-old professor with depression requests you to prescribe an antidepressant that would be least likely to cause sexual dysfunction. Which of the following drugs would you prescribe?
questions.solution:
Bupropion is a suitable option as it reduces the likelihood of sexual dysfunction.

It works by enhancing noradrenergic and dopaminergic neurotransmission through the inhibition of reuptake.
Bupropion is effective for smoking cessation and can also be used to treat depression, especially when combined with SSRIs.
Potential side effects include stimulant-related symptoms such as tachycardia, insomnia, headaches, and an increased risk of seizures in patients with anorexia or bulimia.

Unlike many other antidepressants, it has a lower risk of causing sexual dysfunction and weight gain.
Venlafaxine is classified as a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) and is employed in treating major depression, generalized anxiety disorder, and panic disorder. Its side effects may include nausea, sexual dysfunction, and persistent increases in blood pressure.

Escitalopram and fluoxetine are selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) commonly used for major depression, obsessive-compulsive disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder, bulimia nervosa, anorexia nervosa, and generalized anxiety disorders. Common side effects associated with these medications include dry mouth, urinary retention, and sexual dysfunction.

questions.text: A 30 year old man presented with symptoms of low mood, decreased self esteem,loss of appetite, sleep disturbance, recurrent death wishes since the past one month. He has been on treatment for similar complaints in the past. He has no history of elated mood, racing thoughts, violent behaviour. What could be the possible diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Major depressive disorder (MDD) is a psychiatric disorder characterized by low mood, anhedonia (lack of interest in usual activities), loss of appetite, insomnia or hypersomnia, fatigue, feelings of worthlessness, and/or suicidal thoughts. Decreased serotonin, norepinephrine or dopamine secretion by neurons is implicated in the development of depression.
Recurrent depressive disorder consists of feelings of hopelessness, hollowness, and low self-esteem lasting less than two-week intervals. Patients with the disorder would meet the diagnostic criteria for major depressive disorder if their episodes lasted longer
Ref-Kaplan & Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry 11th Edition • Page 383

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic presented with memory loss and confabulations. On evaluation he was found to have fine tremors. What is the likely diagnosis
questions.solution: Korsakoff psychosis is characterized by amnesia for recent events, impaired ability to learn new facts and fabricated descriptions of recent events (confabulation). The disease results from a symmetrical lesion in the periaqueductal area, thalamus, mammillary bodies and cerebellar vermis; chronic alcoholism associated with thiamine deficiency is an important cause of korsakoff psychosis. Ref- Kaplan and Sadock 11th edition Page 630-633

questions.text: Which cluster would a person with a shy, neurotic, or avoidant personality fall under?
questions.solution:
A person with a shy, anxious-avoidant personality comes under cluster C.


 
  • People with Avoidant Personality Disorder are often shy, sensitive to criticism, and avoid social situations due to fear of rejection or humiliation. They may also have low self-esteem and feelings of inadequacy.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 746-750.

questions.text: A woman who frequently spends a lot of time hand-washing visits the psychiatrist. Although she is upset about it, she claims that she cannot quit practicing because she invests so much time in it. Her social life has also started to suffer as a result of this. What kind of care would be most effective for her?
questions.solution:
• Correct Option is 2: EXPOSURE AND RESPONSE PREVENTION
     
  • The given clinical vignette describes the clinical condition called OCD – Obsessive Compulsive Disorder.
  • Management of OCD: DOC – SSRI; Antipsychotic drugs like Clomipramine, Risperidone, Aripiprazole can be given in SSRI Resistant cases. Psychotherapy of choice- CBT
  •  Exposure and response prevention should commonly be included in the cognitive behavorial therapy in OCD. Thus Exposure and Response prevention is a more specific answer than CBT. 
Some important points to remember among different psychotherapies which are frequently asked in exams:-

•            PTSD --- EMDR (Eye Movement Desensitisation and Reprocessing); however the most effective therapy is CBT.
•            OCD ---- ERP (Exposure Response Prevention) included in CBT.
•            Phobia—Systemic Desensitisation – (It includes 3 steps: - Desensitisation of stimulus, Relaxation training, graded exposure)
•            Substance Use Disorder – Motivational Interviewing]

{Regarding MCQ frequently asked PTSD – EMDR (4 letters); OCD – CBT, ERP (3 letters)} --- Trick to remember it fast.



Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 425.

questions.text: Which of the following approaches to treating post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is the most effective?
questions.solution:
• Both Trauma focussed Cognitive behavioral therapy and Eye movement desensitization and reprocessing have been shown to be efficacious for therapy for the treatment of PTSD.
  • Most meta-analysis/systematic reviews have shown them to have equal efficacy. 
  • The Better answer however would be option (1). CBT is more accessible, and more widely used and the component of eye movement in EMDR has been questioned.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 438, 445.

choices.text: Recall of events and avoidance of trauma

questions.text: What distinguishes PTSD from all other disorders?
questions.solution:
The distinguishing feature of Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) from other disorders is:

1. Recall of events and avoidance of trauma.

This is because re-experiencing the traumatic event (through intrusive memories, flashbacks, or nightmares) and avoidance (avoiding reminders of the trauma, such as places, people, or activities that may trigger memories of the event) are hallmark symptoms of PTSD. These symptoms are unique to PTSD and distinguish it from other mental health disorders.

Here’s why the other options aren’t as distinguishing:

  • Option 2 (Nightmares about events): While nightmares are a common symptom of PTSD, they are not exclusive to this disorder. Other anxiety or trauma-related disorders can also involve nightmares.
  • Option 3 (Autonomic arousal and anxiety): Increased arousal and anxiety can occur in several disorders, including generalized anxiety disorder, panic disorder, and others.
  • Option 4 (Depression): Depression is a symptom that can be present in various disorders, not just PTSD.

The re-experiencing and avoidance elements are what most clearly define PTSD as a unique disorder.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 440-442.

questions.text:
An earthquake wrecked the home of an elderly woman 3 weeks ago. She then arrived to your office and spoke of feeling anxious, depressed, sad, sleep deprived, angry, and frustrated since then. Take into account the following claims:
a. The lady is suffering from acute stress disorder
b. The defense mechanism involved is projection
c. The therapy of choice in this situation is risperidone
d. She needs a referral to a psychiatrist for psychotherapy

Which of the following statements are true?
questions.solution:
• The elderly lady in the above scenario is suffering from Acute Stress Disorder.
  • She needs a psychotherapy session with a psychiatrist.


Acute Stress Disorder
 

  • Acute stress disorder is a common occurrence that starts after a traumatic incident. It occurs for a duration of >48 hours to less than 1 month. Often it subsides within a few days.
  • Projection is not used as a defensive strategy. After a traumatic event, psychological treatment can help with the acute stress reaction.
  • As a result, referral to a psychiatrist is more crucial than antipsychotic medications like risperidone. 
  • Preferred drug in Acute stress disorder is SSRI rather than antipsychotic.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 442, 445.

questions.text: The court has referred someone to you. Between the results of the examination and the history, you discover a discrepancy. Which of these conditions in this circumstance should you be mindful of?
questions.solution:
• Malingering is the practise of fabricating or exaggerating the signs of mental or physical disorders for a number of "secondary gain" objectives, such as monetary gain (often associated with fraud), evading school, work, or military service, obtaining drugs, obtaining lighter sentences for crimes, or simply to garner sympathy or attention
  • Factitious disorder, is a condition where an individual intentionally produces or feigns physical or psychological symptoms for no apparent external gain.
  • Somatization syndrome, is a condition where an individual experiences multiple, recurring physical symptoms that have no apparent medical cause
  • Dissociative fugue, is a condition where an individual experiences a sudden, unexpected episode of amnesia and may wander away from their home or place of work


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 470, 474, 476.

questions.text: Which of these is not true about the Kluver-Bucy syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Visual agnosia, hypersexuality, hyperorality and hypermetamorphosis are characteristics of Kluver-Bucy syndrome.
  • However, intractable seizures are not seen in this. 
  • Kluver-Bucy Syndrome (KBS) is a rare neurological disorder caused by damage to the medial temporal lobes of the brain.
  • The condition is characterized by hypersexuality, oral behaviors such as hyperoralism and pica, and an overall lack of fear.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 14, 518.

questions.text: Which of these is not true about obsession?
questions.solution:
• Obsession has been variably described as disorder or content of thought/possession of thought. However, for the above question option (1), (2), and (3) are correct statements, and hence, option (4) can be considered the incorrect and the best answer for this question.
  • Controversial: Fish's Clinical Psychopathology describes obsession as a disorder of possession of thought. Whereas, Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry (11th edition) list it under disorder of content of thought.
  • AIIMS follows Fish's Clinical Psychopathology as a Standard reference book - hence for INICET- Obessesion is disorder of the possession of thought.

Reference: Fish's Clinical Psychopathology: signs and Symptoms in Psychiatry, 4th edition, Page no 46, 87.
Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 308.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is suffering from depression, palpitations, appetite loss, and insomnia. No complaints of helplessness or suicidal ideation have been made, and there is no prior evidence of any triggering event. In other areas of her life, she is remarkably successful. Her social life and work activities are both going about normally. What is the likely diagnosis in this situation
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario describes a condition called MIXED ANXIETY AND DEPRESSION.
  • By ruling out the different options, option (2) seems the best possible answer in this case.
  • Option (1) GAD- This case doesn’t describe GAD or Generalized Anxiety Disorder as it has been clearly mentioned in the question that all other areas of her life are fine and all her activities are normal. On the contrary, in GAD a person always feels anxious irrespective of time and place.
  • Option (3) Adjustment Disorder - It has been clearly mentioned that her social life and work activities are normal thereby ruling out this option.
  • Option (4) Mild depression - It doesn’t fulfill the basic criteria of BECK’S COGNITIVE TRIAD OF DEPRESSION which includes hopelessness, helplessness, and worthlessness.
  • Option(2) Mixed Anxiety Depression - It’s a condition where the person experiences symptoms of both anxiety and depression ( as described in this question)


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 415, 416.

questions.text: A first-year MBBS who was complaining of periodic episodes of a sense of impending doom and extreme perspiration visited the OPD. The events typically happen just before her examinations. Which diagnosis is more likely?
questions.solution:
• Panic attack is a sudden period of intense fear or apprehension that can last for minutes or hours.
  • People with panic disorder may have recurrent unexpected panic attacks without a trigger.
  • Common symptoms of a panic attack are extreme fear, a sense of impending doom, and anticipatory anxiety.
  • Other causes of panic attacks include exposure to certain panicogen substances such as carbon dioxide, yohimbine, cholecystokinin, and caffeine. This can also cause a situational predisposed panic attack in response to a trigger.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 394.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient complaining of having persistent feelings that his hands are dirty even though they are not visits the psychiatry OPD. He is aware that these are merely his thoughts. He feels discomfort from this, so he has to wash them time and time again. This is a mental disease of:
questions.solution:
• Obsessive-compulsive disorder is a disorder of possession of thought.
  • Obsessions are thoughts that cause stress and compulsions are actions taken to counter that stress.
  • Controversial: Fish's Clinical Psychopathology describes obsession as a disorder of possession of thought. Whereas, Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry (11th edition) list it under disorder of content of thought.
  • AIIMS follows Fish's Clinical Psychopathology as a Standard reference book - hence for INICET- Obessesion is disorder of the possession of thought.


Reference: Fish's Clinical Psychopathology: signs and Symptoms in Psychiatry, 4th edition, Page no 46, 87.
Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 308.

choices.text: Depression is a common comorbidity in OCD
Atypical antipsychotics are the first line treatment
Prevalence of OCD in general public is 7-10%

questions.text: Which of the following statements about OCD is correct?
questions.solution:
• OCD is a thought possession disorder in which a person has intrusive thoughts (obsessions) and/or feels the need to perform certain routines repeatedly (compulsions) to an extent where it induces distress or impairs one’s general functioning.
  • One of the most common types of obsession is “fear of contamination” and " Pathological doubt". (option 2 is incorrect)
  • SSRIs are the first line of treatment. (option 3 is incorrect)
  • The prevalence of OCD in the general public is 2% - 3%. (option 4. is incorrect)
  • It is commonly associated with depression, anxiety, and distress. 


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 418-425.

choices.text: Suicide- self-harm without an intention of causing death.
Overworking- excess work but according to ones capacity.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old physician works in the emergency room and frequently works at night.
Which of the following statements about his mental health is correct?
questions.solution:
The syndrome of burnout is thought to be brought on by ongoing workplace stress that has not been effectively controlled. It has three characteristics:
  1. emotions of weariness or depletion of energy; 
  2. increasing mental detachment from one's employment; sentiments of pessimism or cynicism regarding one's career; 
  3. Decreased professional efficacy. 
  • Depression is a mental health condition that significantly impairs daily life and is characterized by a persistently depressed mood or loss of interest in activities.    
  • Suicide is self-directed, possibly harmful conduct that is non fatal and has the primary goal of causing death. 
  • Working more than your typical working hours and beyond your capacity is referred to as overworking.



Reference: Ventriglio, Antonio et al. “Suicide among doctors: A narrative review.” Indian journal of psychiatry vol. 62,2 (2020): 114-120. doi:10.4103/psychiatry.IndianJPsychiatry_767_19
Kishor, M et al. “Suicide among Indian doctors.” Indian journal of psychiatry vol. 63,3 (2021): 279-284. doi:10.4103/psychiatry.IndianJPsychiatry_137_20

questions.text: Select the most common manifestation of obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD) in adults:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Pathological doubt
 
  • The most common pattern is an obsession of contamination, followed by washing or accompanied by compulsive avoidance of the presumably contaminated object.
  • Pathological doubt is the 2nd most frequent form of obsession, commonly paired with a compulsive need to check something.
  • Such obsessions might involve feeling of potential danger, triggered by thoughts such as forgetting to turn off the stove or not locking a door, and often result in anxiety. Checking behaviours can result in multiple trips back to the house to double-check the stove or door.
  • Since, in this question Contamination is not given in option, so the best answer should be (1) Pathological doubt.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 422.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man claims that there is an odorous scent everywhere that isn't actually there. The most typical location for a lesion would be:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: TEMPORAL LOBE
 
  • The given clinical vignette describes a condition called PHANTOSMIA. This is a type of Olfactory hallucination where an odorous scent is perceived in the absence of identifiable stimulus.
  • These can also be described as olfactory hallucinations.
  • These are commonly seen in TEMPORAL LOBE EPILEPSY or certain brain tumors like GLIOBLASTOMA.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 343.

questions.text: The classical triad of Wernicke's encephalopathy does not include which of the following:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: AUTONOMIC DYSFUNCTION

The components/triad of WERNICKE’S ENCEPHALOPATHY are:
  1. GLOBAL CONFUSION
  2. OPHTHALMOPLEGIA
  3. ATAXIA
[TRICK TO REMEMBER IT FAST – GOA]

The following table is to summarise WERNICKE’S ENCEPHALOPATHY & KORSOKOFF SYNDROME since it is a very frequently asked topic:




Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 796, 797.

questions.text: A person who was missing from home is discovered purposelessly wandering. He appears well-groomed and denies any forgetfulness. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: DISSOCIATIVE FUGUE

The given clinical vignette describes the clinical condition called DISSOCIATIVE FUGUE, which belongs to the spectrum of Dissociative Disorders.




Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 451, 452.

questions.text: In which of the following situations are delusions not seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: CONVERSION DISORDER
  • Delusions are commonly associated with Paranoid type of Schizophrenia.
  • Delusions are found in Major Depression with psychotic features.
  • Dementia can also commonly be associated with delusion.
Hence by ruling out the options Conversion Disorder is the most appropriate answer to this question.

CONVERSION DISORDER –
  • Functional Neurologic symptom disorder.
  • It is an unexplained loss of sensory or motor function.
  • Stressor is present. [Important point frequently asked ]
  • Commonly seen in females adolescents young adults.
  • Characterised by Primary gain, Secondary gain, La belle indifference, Identification ; Positive  HOOVER TEST ; Astasia abasia; Pseudo paralysis
IMPORTANT BUZZWORDS FREQUENTLY TESTED ARE:-
 
    1. LA BELLE INDIFFERENCE – Indifference towards symptoms
    2. ASTASIA ABASIA – Abnormal gait in the absence of any structural cause


    2.  

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 474, 475.

questions.text: A 15 years old girl is having irresistible desire to eat. She also takes appetite suppressants. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in the above clinical scenario is bulimia nervosa. 
 
  • It is an eating disorder characterized by binge-eating episodes followed by compensatory mechanisms in the form of self induced vomiting, diuretics or laxative abuse. The weight of the patient is near normal. 
 
  • This has to be distinguished from binge eating disorder wherein excessive binge eating episodes are not followed by compensatory mechanisms. This makes the patient overweight/obese. 



Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 363, 509, 511, 512, 514.

questions.text:
Match the following: 
1. Kleptomania A. Compulsive alcohol drinking
2. Dipsomania B. Mutilating animals
3.  Multilomania C. Set fire
4. Pyromania D. Compulsive stealing
questions.solution:
• Kleptomania : compulsive stealing
  • Dipsomania : compulsive alcohol drinking
  • Multilomania : hurt/torture animals
  • Pyromania : urge to set fire


Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 611-613.

questions.text: A 32-year old female presents with complaints of repeated episodes of around 30 minutes characterized by breathlessness, palpitations, sweating, hyperventilation and a fear of impending heart attack. The patient has been having these episodes 4-5 times in one month, for the last 6 months, and the investigations didn’t reveal any specific findings. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A middle aged female with episodes of hyperventilation and palpitations with a fear of impending doom lasting for about 30 minutes multiple times every month over the last 6 months represents recurrent attacks, establishing a diagnosis of panic disorder.
 
  • Generalized anxiety disorder is characterized by chronic, multiple worries, anxiety and increased tension. This patient experiences recurrent, unexpected panic attacks. (option B)
  • Depression is characterized by sadness and anhedonia as the core features, with the diagnostic features popularly abbreviated as SIGECAPS. (option C)
  • Social anxiety disorder or social phobia involves anxiety restricted to social or performance situations with a fear of scrutiny and embarrassment. (option D)
Reference: KAPLAN & SADOCK’S Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page. No- 394,396.

questions.text: A 32 year old male patient presents to psychiatry OPD with a history of recurrent premature ejaculation leading to interpersonal conflict. Which of the following is the non pharmacological treatment of choice ?
questions.solution:
Pharmacologic therapy when combined with behavioral treatment appears to be more effective in treating premature ejaculation:
  1. SSRIs including paroxetine are the first-line treatment.
  2. The squeeze technique is a behavioral method used on the penis to prevent premature ejaculation. Here, the penis is stimulated until just before orgasm after which it is gently squeezed. It is particularly useful when psychogenic and/ or relationship factors are present such as the interpersonal conflict in this case.
  • Sensate focus therapy is a couple-oriented sex therapy that involves the exchange of sensual touch between partners to alleviate anxiety and negativity associated with sex and to build better sexual intimacy and communication. It is useful for the management of psychogenic erectile dysfunction. (option A)
  • Although cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) can be beneficial for some patients with sexual dysfunction. It is not a specific technique for managing PE.(option C)
  • Exposure and response prevention therapy is a strategy effective in the management of OCD.  (option D)
Reference: KAPLAN & SADOCK’S Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page. No- 577, 579.

questions.text: The finding of the immunohistochemistry studies of a patient with a neurodegenerative disease is given below. Identify the structure marked in the image.
questions.solution:
The provided histological sample of the substantia nigra reveals characteristic features associated with Parkinson's disease:

Key Findings:

Lewy Bodies:

These are intracytoplasmic inclusions that can appear single or multiple. They are typically round to elongated, eosinophilic (stain well with eosin), and often have a dense core surrounded by a pale halo. Lewy bodies are primarily composed of alpha-synuclein and ubiquitin, which are proteins that aggregate within neurons.
Extracellular Neuromelanin:

The substantia nigra contains a significant amount of neuromelanin, a pigment that accumulates within dopaminergic neurons. In Parkinson‘s disease, the loss of these neurons leads to a relative increase in neuromelanin in the surrounding areas.
Pigment-Laden Macrophages:

These macrophages may appear in response to the cellular degeneration and can be indicative of the body's immune response to neuronal loss in the substantia nigra.

questions.text: A 7 year old child is noted to be extremely naughty, unable to sit in a place for a long time, excessively talking, and unable to concentrate on a thing for a long time. Which of the following drug is used in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
• The child presents with inattention, hyperactivity, impulsivity, and difficulty sustaining focus, which are classic features of Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD).

  • Methylphenidate is a central nervous system stimulant that increases dopamine and norepinephrine levels in the brain, improving attention, focus, and impulse control.

  • Other options:

    • Atenolol: A beta-blocker, used for cardiovascular conditions and sometimes off-label for anxiety, not ADHD.

    • Modafinil: A wakefulness-promoting agent, used in narcolepsy, not first-line for ADHD.

    • Amitriptyline: A tricyclic antidepressant, used for depression, neuropathic pain, enuresis, not ADHD.

questions.text: SCOFF protocol is used for assessing:
questions.solution:
The SCOFF questionnaire is a brief screening tool used to identify potential cases of eating disorders, specifically anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa.

It consists of five key questions [Abbreviated as SCOFF] that focus on the main characteristics of these conditions:

1. Do you induce vomiting/make yourself Sick because you feel overly full?

2. Do you worry about losing Control over your eating?

3. Have you recently lost more than One stone (approximately 6.35 kg) within three months?

4. Do you see yourself as Fat even though others say you are too thin?

5. Does Food play an overwhelmingly important role in your life?


If a person answers “Yes” to two or more of these questions, it suggests a higher likelihood of anorexia or bulimia.



Reference: Morgan, J F et al. “The SCOFF questionnaire: a new screening tool for eating disorders.” The Western journal of medicine vol. 172,3 (2000): 164-5. doi:10.1136/ewjm.172.3.164. URL: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC1070794/

questions.text: Which of the following does not suggest a medical cause of mental illness?
questions.solution:
Auditory hallucinations are typically not indicative of a medical cause for mental illness.

Hallucinations are defined as perceptions that occur without corresponding external stimuli.

Auditory hallucinations are the most frequently encountered type in psychiatric settings. In contrast, nonauditory hallucinations often point to underlying neurological, medical, or substance withdrawal issues rather than a primary psychiatric disorder.

Features Suggesting a Medical Cause of Mental Illness:
Acute onset: Symptoms develop rapidly (within hours or minutes), often with prevailing symptoms.
Older age: Patients tend to be older.
Current medical illness or injury: There is often a concurrent medical condition.
Significant substance abuse: A history of substantial substance use may be present.
Nonauditory disturbances of perception: These disturbances may indicate an underlying medical issue.
Neurological symptoms: Signs such as loss of consciousness, seizures, recent head injury, changes in headache pattern, or visual changes may occur.
Classic mental status signs: These include diminished alertness, disorientation, memory impairment, difficulty with concentration and attention, dyscalculia, and concreteness in thought processes.
Other mental status signs: Patients may exhibit speech, movement, or gait disorders.
Constructional apraxia: Difficulties in tasks such as drawing clocks, cubes, intersecting pentagons, or completing the Bender-Gestalt test may be observed.

questions.text: A 18 year old girl with intense food cravings and a constant worry of weight gain induces forceful vomiting after consumption of food. However she has a BMI of 27kg/m2. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Anorexia nervosa Bulimia nervosa Binge-eating disorder
Avoidance of food
(calorie deficit)		 + - -
Binge eating +/- + +
Compensation (purge/vomit) +/- + -
BMI Reduced Normal Elevated

The given clinical history is suggestive of Bulimia nervosa.
Bulimia nervosa is an eating disorder, often seen in young women.
It is characterized by binge-eating episodes, followed by inappropriate, compensatory measures to stop weight gain, like self-induced vomiting, laxative abuse, diuretics, enema, and emetic abuse. These binge-eating episodes occur at least once a week and are present for at least 3 months. The patient fears gaining weight and has a relentless drive to be thin, however these patients tend to have normal BMI.
Anorexia nervosa is an eating disorder that is often seen between the ages of 10 and 30. Typical features are self-induced starvation, voluntary and unhealthy reduction in weight, intense drive for thinness, and fear of becoming obese.
Binge-eating disorder is the most common eating disorder. It is characterized by rapid intake of abnormally large quantities of food over a short period of time, even when not hungry. There are feelings of guilt about the eating episodes, but these patients do not compensate in any way following the episodes of binge. Ref: Kaplan & Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry 11th Edition
• Page no 363, 509, 511, 512, 514, 516-520

questions.text: Which of the following defense mechanisms is likely to be present in this patients with phobic disorder?
questions.solution: Displacement is the defense mechanism in phobias. It is the shifting of emotions about one object/individual onto another object/individual. Ref- Kaplan and Sadock 12th edition table 34-12

questions.text: Intense fear of crowded places is called?
questions.solution:
Agoraphobia is the fear of crowded places .
Acarophobia is the fear of small objects.
Acrophobia is the fear of high places. Androphobia is the fear of men. Ref- Kaplan and Sadock textbook of child and adolescent Psychiatry 10th edition Page 11583

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden irresistible urges to do things that come to his mind. Which of the following best describes this symptom?
questions.solution:
An impulse is a sudden, irresistible urge to perform an act, often without rational planning. It is usually recognized by the patient as unwanted or inappropriate, but they feel compelled to act on it. Examples include impulsive stealing, fire-setting, or aggressive acts.

Other options:

  1. Delusion: A firmly held false belief that is not amenable to logic or reasoning and is not based in reality.

  2. Hallucination: A perception without external stimulus, such as hearing voices or seeing things that aren’t there.

  3. Illusion: A misperception or misinterpretation of a real external stimulus, like seeing a rope and thinking it is a snake.

Key point: Impulses are behavioral urges, whereas delusions, hallucinations, and illusions are perceptual or cognitive phenomena.



Reference:The essentials of forensic medicine and toxicology 33rd edition page no 482

questions.text: Which among the following is the key feature of depression?
questions.solution:
Depression is characterized by a constellation of emotional, cognitive, and somatic symptoms. Among these, the key diagnostic feature is:

  • Loss of interest or pleasure in previously enjoyable activities (anhedonia).

Other symptoms such as feelings of worthlessness, suicidal thoughts, and changes in appetite are common but are supporting features rather than the core symptom.


Reference:Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry 11th edition page no 355,1408

questions.text: What trait is not present in autism?
questions.solution:
• The trait that is not present in autism is "All patients are mentally retarded". Intellectual disability is commonly associated with autism (upto 50% of autistic children have an Intellectual disability) but not all autistic children are mentally retarded.
  • Intelligence levels can vary widely among individuals with autism, and some may even have above-average intelligence.
  • The other three traits mentioned in the question, poor eye contact, impaired language, and abnormal dermatoglyphics (unusual patterns on the skin of the fingers, palms, and soles), are all commonly associated with autism.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 1153, 1156.

questions.text: Which of the following is not present in a child with a pervasive developmental disorder?
questions.solution:
• DSM-V recommends that intellectual disability should be ruled out before pervasive developmental abnormalities are identified.
  •  Pervasive developmental disorders (POD) is characterized by delays in the development of a variety of fundamental abilities, such as socializing and communication.
  • While some children with PDDs may have cognitive impairments, this is not a defining characteristic of the disorder. Instead, the hallmark features of PDDs are difficulties with social interaction and communication, as well as the presence of repetitive or stereotyped behaviors.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 1164, 1165.

questions.text: Vegetables are not being eaten by a child. Each time he finishes a serving of vegetables, his mother starts giving him a chocolate. The condition is described as:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Operant conditioning 
 
  • The technique used in this case by the mother is known as operant conditioning.
  • In operant conditioning, a reward or punishment system is used to inculcate some specific behavior. In the given scenario, chocolates are used as rewards.
  • Operant conditioning is a type of learning in which behavior is strengthened or weakened by the consequences that follow it. In this scenario, the child's behavior of finishing a serving of vegetables is being reinforced by the reward of receiving a chocolate. This reward serves as a positive reinforcement, making it more likely that the child will repeat the behavior of finishing their vegetables in the future.
  • Classical conditioning is a learning process that occurs when two stimuli are repeatedly paired: a response which is at first elicited by the second stimulus is eventually elicited by the first stimulus alone.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 101-103.

questions.text: Minimal dysfunction syndrome has been observed in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: ADHD
 
  • Minimal Dysfunction Syndrome/ Minimal Brain Dysfunction is the old term used to describe a condition which is now popularly known as  (ADHD).
  • The hypothesis that minimal brain damage may lead to behavior disorders became well established. In the 1960s, however, many critics emerged who criticized the tests commonly used in the assessment of brain damage and challenged the argument that every child presenting with abnormal behavior was to have minimal brain damage

 
Reference: Lange, Klaus W et al. “The history of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.” Attention deficit and hyperactivity disorders vol. 2,4 (2010): 241-55. doi:10.1007/s12402-010-0045-8. 
Kaplan and Sadock's Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry (e-book), 10th edition, Page no 8230.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy struggles to do well on his ninth-grade exam. But he is incredibly intelligent and sharp. what is the best test to identify his issue?
questions.solution:
• Best test to diagnose his problem is specific learning disability test. (Option 3)
  • Triad of Specific Learning Disorders is: Dyslexia, Dysgraphia, and Dyscalculia.
  • Given that the child in the question is sharp and intelligent but not able to get good grades this image strongly suggests the presence of a "specific learning disability" disorder, which is best identified by a specific learning disability test.



Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 1182-1184.

questions.text: A child is not eating any vegetables. Every time he finishes the last vegetable in his diet, his mother starts giving him a chocolate. What's the condition?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Operant conditioning 
 
  • The technique used in this case by the mother is known as operant conditioning.
  • In operant conditioning, a reward or punishment system is used to inculcate some specific behavior. In the given scenario, chocolates are used as rewards.
  • Operant conditioning is a type of learning in which behavior is strengthened or weakened by the consequences that follow it. In this scenario, the child's behavior of finishing a serving of vegetables is being reinforced by the reward of receiving a chocolate. This reward serves as a positive reinforcement, making it more likely that the child will repeat the behavior of finishing their vegetables in the future.
  • Classical conditioning is a learning process that occurs when two stimuli are repeatedly paired: a response which is at first elicited by the second stimulus is eventually elicited by the first stimulus alone.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 101-103.

questions.text: Upon presentation, a two-year-old boy has delayed speech and communication abilities. He has trouble focusing and isn't establishing any friends. He has also been seen continually gazing intently at his own hands. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: AUTISM
The given clinical vignette describes condition called AUTISM which belong to the spectrum of Autism Spectrum Disorders.

The buzzwords given in the question which helped us reach the diagnosis are:
  1. Delayed speech
  2. Trouble in focusing
  3. Trouble in establishing friends ( poor communication )
  4.  Continuously gazing intently at his own hands (Persistent preoccupation with objects or parts.)
A few important points to remember about AUTISM SPECTRUM DISORDERS are:
•            They are Pervasive disorders.
•            They are characterised by impairment in social interaction and communication, delay in developing and understanding peer relationships, reduced eye contact, delayed development of speech, fixated interest, persistent preoccupation with parts of object.
•            Ambidextrous, no association with dermatoglyphics, precocious skills, mental retardation seen in 2/3 of patients. However they generally don’t have impaired cognition. {A few one liners frequently given as stems in MCQ questions}
•            This spectrum includes a number of conditions like AUTISM, RETT, ASPERGER, HELLER.



Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 1155-1157.

questions.text: Except for____scholastic achievement is affected in all of the following.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: PICA
Among the given options PICA is the most suitable answer.

ADHD (Option 1):
  • Timeline - > 6 months
  • Age of onset - < 12 yrs
  • Presence of INATTENTIVE SYMPTOMS or/ and HYPERACTIVE or IMPULSIVE SYMPTOMS in at least 2 SETTINGS (home and school).
  • Subtypes – Predominantly Inattentive, Predominantly hyperactive, Combined symptoms of both
  • These children have normal intelligence but commonly face difficulties in school. It can also persist into adulthood.
  • ADHD kids have the risk of developing Alcoholism, Antisocial Personality Disorder.
  • Treatment – Behavioral therapy; Age <6yrs – ATOMOXETINE, α2 adrenergic agonist like CLONIDINE, GUANFACINE; Age >6yrs – Stimulant drugs can be given like METHYLPHENIDATE, AMPHETAMINES.
[VERY IMPORTANT POINT FREQUENTLY ASKED – Less than 6 yrs age stimulants cannot be given because it causes retardation of growth.]

[1 TRICK TO REMEMBER IN ADHD - 6×2=12 àTimeline: 6 months; at 2 settings; Onset before 12 yrs]

SPECIFIC LEARNING DISABILTY (Option 2):
  • Timeline > 6 months
  • Inability to acquire information of a specific subject
  • General functioning and intelligence are normal
  • Treatment – Academic support and counselling

PICA
  • Timeline >1 month
  • Repeated episodes of eating non-food substances
  • Commonly seen in children and during pregnancy
  • Can also be associated with malnutrition, iron deficiency anaemia
  • Treatment – Psychotherapy Nutritional rehabilitation SSRI
 ANXIETY (Option 3): Its self-explanatory that too much anxiety will definitely affect the scholastic performance.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 1206.

questions.solution:
Cognitive impairment doesn't form the criteria for Autism Spectrum disorder. Below is the DSM-5 criteria for Autism Spectrum Disorder.



Reference: KAPLAN & SADOCK’S Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page No 1156.

questions.text: A patient is obsessed with keeping herself clean. She washes her hands multiple times and is yet never satisfied with her cleanliness. She even refuses to go out because she is afraid of getting contaminated. Which phase of development are these personality traits related to?
questions.solution:
The described behavior — excessive concern with cleanliness, orderliness, and control — corresponds to obsessive-compulsive traits. In psychodynamic theory:

  • These traits are linked to the anal stage of psychosexual development (approximately 1–3 years of age).

  • Anal stage characteristics: Focus on control, order, cleanliness, and retention/expulsion issues.

  • Fixation at this stage can manifest in adulthood as:

    • Obsessive-compulsive personality traits

    • Perfectionism

    • Rigidity and preoccupation with cleanliness

Other stages for context:

  • Oral stage: Fixation leads to dependency, passivity, or oral habits (e.g., smoking, overeating).

  • Phallic stage: Focuses on genital awareness and Oedipal conflicts.

  • Genital stage: Mature sexual relationships develop; fixation here does not typically produce obsessive-compulsive traits.



Reference:Kaplan and Saddock's Synopsis of Psychiatry 11th edition page no 157

questions.text: A schizophrenic patient with agitation and violent behaviour was being treated with haloperidol. He became rigid after that and couldn't even move his eyes. Which medication should be included in his intravenous therapy for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Promethazine
 
  • Rigidity and inability to move eyes after haloperidol use in a patient of Schizophrenia is highly suggestive of Acute muscular dystonia.
  • Treatment with IM anticholinergic (benztropine) or IV/IM antihistaminic (diphenhydramine, Promethazine hydrochloride) almost always relieves the symptoms
  • Promethazine is a first-generation antihistamine with anticholinergic and sedative properties. It is commonly used to treat nausea, vomiting, and motion sickness, but it can also be used to manage acute dystonia caused by antipsychotic medications.
  • Promethazine works by blocking dopamine receptors in the brain, which helps to alleviate the muscle spasms and rigidity associated with acute dystonia.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 782.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman arrives at a clinic with 2 weeks of decreased sleep, increased appetite, and hyperactivity. A manic episode diagnosis is made. Further investigation reveals four episodes of major depression in the previous two years. What medication will you give to this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Haloperidol

Treatment of acute mania:
  1. Utilize mood stabilizers (e.g- Lithium) and antipsychotics.
  2. Antipsychotics are tapered down when the acute episode is under control while mood stabilizers are kept up.
  3. Following the first episode, treatment lasts typically 6 to 9 months.
  • Due to its teratogenicity and high incidence of Ebstein's abnormality, lithium is contraindicated during pregnancy.
  • DOC for acute manic episodes in breastfeeding and pregnancy hence are Antipsychotics. 
  • The sole antipsychotic drug listed here is Haloperidol, which is the correct option.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 377-379.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old boy with schizophrenia has been on risperidone for the past two months and is doing well. There is no history of the illness in his family.
How long should this patient's medicine be continued?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. 2 years
 
  • Numerous randomized trials have demonstrated that continuing antipsychotic therapy lowers the chance of recurrence for up to two years.
Most books mention treatment duration for schizophrenia as:
  • 1st episode: 1-2 years
  • 2nd episode: 2-5 years
  • 3rd/Recurrent: Lifetime
Though there is a controversy between 1 year and 2 years, 2 years is a safer answer than 1 year.



Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 319.

questions.text: A young male patient who has been taking haloperidol 5 mg for some days has suddenly experienced inner restlessness and a need to move. What is the most likely  Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Akathisia
 
  • Following the use of antipsychotics like haloperidol, inward restlessness and the desire to move are strongly predictive of akathisia.
  • Akathisia is characterized by subjectively felt restlessness, externally seen indicators of restlessness or both. Examples include feeling anxious, having trouble relaxing, being jittery, pacing, rocking back and forth when seated, and frequently standing and sitting.
  • It typically tends to develop 5-50 days post antipsychotic initiation and management includes using drugs like Propranolol/Benzodiazepines.




Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 780.

questions.text: Which of the following medicines can be immediately stopped without causing withdrawal symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Fluoxetine
 
  • Fluoxetine can be stopped abruptly without any withdrawal symptoms due to its long half life [t1/2= 2 days].
  • It is the longest acting SSRI.
  • Side-effects of the fluoxetine discontinuation are unusual and very mild, especially compared to paroxetine, venlafaxine and fluvoxamine, owing to the relatively long pharmacological half-life of fluoxetine.
  • Other short acting SSRIs, including Escitalopram, Fluvoxamine, and Sertraline, have shorter half-lives and are more likely to cause withdrawal symptoms if stopped suddenly. This is known as Discontinuation syndrome.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 488, 489.

questions.text: Which antipsychotic on the list below causes increased prolactin secretion?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: RISPERIDONE
  • It has maximum D2 blocking property amidst the atypical ones. Therefore it will have maximum EPS side effects as well as maximum Prolactin secretion.
  • It has combined D2 + 5-HT2 receptor blocking property. In addition, it has high affinity for α1, α2 and H1 receptors: blockade of these may contribute to efficacy as well as side effects like postural hypotension. However, BP can rise if it is given with a SSRI.
  • Risperidone is more potent D2 blocker than clozapine; extrapyramidal side effects are less only at low doses (<6 mg/day). Prolactin levels rise disproportionately during Risperidone therapy.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 468, 469.

choices.text: Thiazide act as an add-on to Lithium
Thiazide increases the tubular reabsorption of Sodium, decreasing Lithium secretion.
Thiazide cause loss of water thereby increasing Lithium levels

questions.text: A patient with bipolar disorder was started on Thiazides for hypertension. After a couple of days, he developed coarse tremors. Likely reason is:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Thiazide increases the tubular reabsorption of Sodium, decreasing Lithium secretion.
 
  • The likely reason for the development of coarse tremors in a patient with bipolar disorder who was started on Thiazides for hypertension is decreased Lithium secretion due to increased compensatory proximal tubular reabsorption of sodium due to the thiazide use.
  •  Thiazides are known to decrease the renal clearance of Lithium, which can lead to an increase in Lithium levels in the blood. This effect is due to the fact that Thiazides increase the excretion of Sodium in the kidneys at DCT, leading to increased Sodium reabsorption at PCT and decreased Lithium secretion.
  • This can cause Lithium toxicity, which can present with symptoms such as coarse tremors.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 477.

questions.text: What is the initial drug for the management of a patient who recently started on Fluphenazine and after a few weeks developed tremors, rigidity, bradykinesia, and excessive salivation
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Trihexyphenidyl
 
  • Tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia point towards Drug-induced Parkinsonism which is an extrapyramidal side effect observed with Antipsychotic (anti-dopaminergic) drugs like Fluphenazine.
  • Trihexyphenidyl is an anti-cholinergic medication used to manage the neurological adverse reactions associated with the use of antipsychotic (anti-dopaminergic) drugs such as fluphenazine.
  • It helps to reduce these symptoms, providing relief and allowing patients to continue on the antipsychotic course without interruption.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 924.
Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 282.

choices.text: Bladder training with reward for delaying micturition in daytime

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was admitted after having wet the bed twice a week for the previous year. A thorough analysis eliminates an organic reason. What should the initial course of treatment be?
questions.solution:
The child is suffering from Nocturnal Enuresis.
  • Bell and pad based classical conditioning is the most effective treatment modality.
Methods of treating Nocturnal Enuresis:
  1. Reassure parents and tell them about the self limiting nature of the disorder.
  2. Motivational therapy can be used.
  3. Conditioning with Bell and pad alarm method can be used.
  4. Pharmacotherapy- DOC Imipramine 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 1216.

questions.text: TCA was administered to a patient in the hospital for 4 weeks in order to treat a serious depressive episode. Which of the following are your primary worries while thinking about his discharge
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: SUICIDAL RISK
 
  • Among the given options suicidal risk is the most appropriate answer and since its one of the most common and important psychiatric emergencies and should be kept in mind while discharging a patient.
  • Suicidal behaviours are common side effects of Tricyclic Antidepressants (TCA) because the energy level rises with administration of antidepressants, thus attempting suicide can increase which is the paradox, and thus the attendants should be warned about this while planning to discharge the patient.


Reference: Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 271, 276.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy complained of c/o bedwetting nearly twice a week. To rule out any organic cause, a thorough investigation
was conducted. Parents and child are concerned about his condition. What early management is most effective?
questions.solution:
The child is suffering from Nocturnal Enuresis.
  • Bell and pad based classical conditioning is the most effective treatment modality.
Methods of treating Nocturnal Enuresis:
  1. Reassure parents and tell them about the self limiting nature of the disorder.
  2. Motivational therapy can be used.
  3. Conditioning with Bell and pad alarm method can be used.
  4. Pharmacotherapy

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 1216.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for the treatment of OCD?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: SERTRALINE
The drug of choice for the treatment of OCD is SSRI.

The different examples of SSRI include Sertraline, Escitalopram, Fluoxetine, Fluvoxamine, Paroxetine.

Imp points to remember about OCD:-
•            The common symptoms seen in OCD are Contamination (most common) > Pathological doubt (second most common) > Intrusive thoughts > Symmetry
•            Defence Mechanisms in OCD – Displacement, Undoing, Reaction formation, Inhibition, Isolation of affect (DURII)

Management:
  • DOC – SSRI; Antipsychotic drugs like Clomipramine, Risperidone, Aripiprazole can be given in SSRI Resistant cases.
  • Psychotherapy of choice- Exposure and Response prevention included in CBT



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 489.
Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 425.

questions.text: All of these conditions are treated with repeated transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) of the brain except ?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Generalized Anxiety Disorder
 
  • Repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) is a non-invasive brain stimulation technique that involves the delivery of magnetic pulses to specific regions of the brain.
  • It has been used as a treatment for various psychiatric and neurological disorders such as OCD, Depression, Acute psychosis, Schizophrenia, PTSD. 
  • It has been approved by the FDA as a treatment for major depressive disorder that has not responded to at least one antidepressant medication.
  • The magnetic pulses delivered during rTMS stimulate the prefrontal cortex, which is involved in regulating mood, and can help alleviate symptoms of depression.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 373, 1073-1074

questions.text: A 34-year-old female presented to the psychiatric OPD with low mood, loss of energy, loss of interest in pleasurable activities, decreased sleep, and appetite for the past 2 months. What is the most appropriate treatment to be started?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with low mood, anhedonia, fatigue, insomnia, and decreased appetite for 2 months, which is consistent with a major depressive episode.

  • Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) and is considered first-line treatment for moderate to severe depression.

  • Lithium is primarily used for bipolar disorder and as augmentation in resistant depression.

  • Haloperidol is an antipsychotic, used mainly for psychosis or as adjunct in severe mania.

  • Sodium valproate is a mood stabilizer, mainly used in bipolar disorder.



Reference:Kaplan and Sadock's Consise textbook of clinical Psychiatry 11th edition page no 374
